148896943.review:
NO SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEW

One of the funniest games I've played in my life with a great cast of characters and a zany yet compelling story.

Pros:
- Every case is unique and intriguing, keeping you guessing until the last moments.
- Music is near perfect, almost on par with the Persona games.
- Character dialogue is hilarious and engaging, you actually care about keeping everyone alive.
- Game-play is extremely unique and takes some brainpower to succeed. The truth bullets where you have to shoot down characters arguments with evidence you collect is one of the best uses of mental game-play I have seen in a video game. And its extremely satisfying when you piece together the whole murder at the end of every case.
- Monokuma is one of the most zany and like-able villains in fiction and is the best character in whole game, hands down.
- You will get to know a character so well and you'll become so invested in them that it really shocks you when you realize they are the murder in a case later down the line. One of the few games I've played that does this well.

Cons:
- Too many Japanese people
- There's a couple cases where if the murder just did one simple thing you would never be able to solve the case. A little unrealistic but there's literally a perverted talking robot bear cracking jokes every two seconds so who gives a f word.

10/10

TL;DR
Japanese lawyer fever dream.

148129764.review:
[h1]TL; DR[/h1]
A fever dream of emotions. As more and more cases go by, despair sets in, as beloved characters get killed off or are proven as traitorous killers. While logic and deduction certainly have their place in the game, Danganrompa's heart is in its characters, its atmosphere and its style.

[h1]Wherever there is hope, there is most definitely despair.[/h1]
Okay, so first off - this game is fucking nuts.

The art direction is all over the place - pixelated items among anime-styled portraits, 3D rooms alongside 2D textures. It really is a mess, almost dream-like in its absurdity - and yet this artistic dissonance, perhaps intentionally, only improves its sinister tone.

Due to its constant ping-ponging between humor and horror, the player finds themselves always unprepared for what is to come, lowering their guard with an absurdist skit only to get promptly hit in the face with a character death or an act of terror by the game's main antagonist, Monokuma. Just like the rest of the game, Monokuma seems innocuous at first - a cuddly teddy bear toy - only to prove himself throughout the course of the game as an absolutely vicious creature, yet still maintaining his composure as a 'tee-hee' cute mascot.

This humor, this humanity, I think, is the main drive of the game. Hope is given, and hope is taken - despair taking hold ever more frequently as cases unfold, with beolved characters getting killed off, or proving themselves as traitorous killers. While logic and deduction certainly have their place in the game, I don't think that's the game's focus, with its myriad of minigames and visual novel-esque systems - instead, it lies firmly in its characters, its atmosphere, and its style - which are all very gripping.

147184614.review:
I know there are plenty of people who love the whole Danganronpa franchise, so of course take this with a grain of salt, but for me, I feel that there are other games that do the same job better.  The mysteries you solve are interesting, but the first two mysteries have taken me 3+ hours each to "solve," not because I didn't know the answer, but because the pacing is So Slow.  The time between mysteries is slow, the time to gather evidence is slow, and during the trial, it feels like the game tries to make up for how slow everything else has been by suddenly throwing a bunch of pointless mini games at you.  

Now, in its defense, it clearly was not originally made for PC gaming, so you can tell that some of the slow spots probably would have been more fun to maneuver on a console (some parts feel VERY geared toward touch screen, though that's just a guess), but after playing other detective games, I was really underwhelmed by this one.  I'll probably still finish it (or maybe just watch the anime) to know what happens, but it doesn't feel like something I'll be forcing myself to do rather than wanting to do it out of a sense of enjoyment.  Maybe the other two games are better, though?

147140452.review: I am the number 1 Chihiro fan

147124271.review:
I got this a good few years ago when I was going through a bit of an anime phase in uni, never actually got around to playing it till now, not even sure why in honesty. Visual Novel is not a genre I've ever had much interest in, I have played a grand total one one other game in the genre and that was Doki Doki Literature Club, which I'm not sure even counts. I'm currently trying to learn Japanese, and saw this was a game where you could set the audio to ingrish or to nihongo, so I went with it's original audio to try to get some practice... sadly it's mostly sound bites of a couple of words, but I'm surprised to say I got really drawn in by the story. 

So, the general premise is basically a mix between Battle Royale and Phoneix Wrights. If you don't know either of those, the first is the film and book that Hunger Games was ripping off. Far better as well I might add, it has a class of kids who know each other rather than strangers so there's a lot of interpersonal conflict and drama instead of a bunch of cardboard cutouts for our heroine to blow away for standing between her and her crush. It doesn't shy away from the fact kids being forced to kill kids is horrible, and it also has some masterful black comedy thrown in as well. The latter is a series of legal drama games that feature a guy in a blue suit who yells "OBJECTION". But I digress.

 Anyway, in this game, there is a super exclusive high school in Tokyo, which is attended by invitation only, the students for each year hand picked to be the cream of the crop and the hope for the future. All except yourself, who was the single student picked at random, presumably as a token gesture to keep the plebs happy. Being the odd one out in a school full of intense perfectionists, spoiled rich kids and celebrity divas would be hard enough, but upon entering, you pass out. Upon waking, it becomes apparent that something is very wrong. All of the windows have metal sheets bolted across them, the entrance is now a bank vault door guarded by automated machine guns. An announcement summons you to the gym, where a teddy bear announces that you are now obligated to spend the rest of your natural lives in the school, and that the only way you will "graduate" is by successfully killing another student and not getting caught.

As said, I was surprised at how engaging I ended up finding the story. There's a good amount of drama and intrigue from the premise alone, and there's a few little touches and minor details spaced out throughout that I found really intriguing and kept me going to see what the payoff was. I will admit there is a big plot hole and one or two of the plot elements are a little bit bonkers, but it's quite strong overall. The characters aren't the deepest, but I found I quite liked being around most of them, although a few are dead before you really get to know them and there are two who are so obviously coded as being nasty that there is little surprise when they do. There is another mode you can unlock upon finishing the game that lets you just hang out with them, but I can't say anything about it beyond the fact that it exists. They have enough depth to mostly not come across as being one note, and they do react relatively realistically to being stuck in the situation that they are in. I felt quite bad when certain deaths occurred, and the executions became a surprisingly bittersweet affair when most of the guilty parties were only guilty due to being forced into a horrible situation by the Bear. 

 Speaking of the Bear, he's a really effective villain. He's basically a slightly less evil Mickey Mouse, the high pitched voice, the self obsession, the fact he has to slap his face on everything in sight should be quite familiar. Add to this the facts that he's an open sadist revelling in the pain that he is causing and a near Shodan level of control over the school, and the fact that he's just really obnoxious. Which does make things all the more awkward when he started actually successfully making me laugh as the game went on. He's one of those characters I find I love to hate, which I haven't got much of in media lately so it's nice to see. 

Anyway, on to gameplay, as I can't talk much more about the story without giving spoilers and I've already had to delete several accidental ones. The game runs perfectly well, I had no issues there, and the soundtrack is really nice. The game part of the game has three modes as such. The first is where you walk around the school exploring and being social (or lying in bed to pass time until something interesting happens if you are a speedrunner or have a crippling fear of social interaction or the ambient jazz), the second is where you investigate the murders and gather clues, and the third is the "class trials" where all the characters gather and try to work out who did it, with the Bear making it clear he will execute everyone except the guilty party if the wrong person is picked.  I'm not going to lie, it's fairly simplistic game play, but it is a very heavily story focused game, and it mostly gets the job done. Yes you are somewhat handheld, but the trials are quite exciting and feel suitably climactic as you work through all of the evidence, pick apart weak arguments and try to establish the pattern of events. You have to do a bit of thinking in them, and works as a followup to the investigations. They even have the trials auto save before every one of the in trial mini games so you don't loose a massive chunk of progress when you fail.

As much as I did like the game, I'd be remiss in not offering a few criticisms. It's an anime game, so if you hate the art style or very over the top characters you are probably not going to enjoy this. There are also the inevitable pervy camera angles, which there aren't many of, but they are definitely present. In the social section you wander about the school, and if you find one of the other students you can hang out with them. The issue with this is, as the game goes on and the bodies pile up, is that there's an ever decreasing number of characters, and it can become really hard to actually find anyone when the entire school is open. You can search through the somewhere around twenty rooms, each with a load screen (Which are nicely stylised, but are not the fastest) and not find anyone, and can look for a person in particular only to find out that they are in their room huffing and won't talk to you for this section. I'd really appreciate if the game marked the map or told you where they were, as wandering aimlessly round the school can get pretty annoying. Some of the minigames in the trials also feel a bit pointless. If a person is shouting you play a rhythm game, which I never understood but got through entirely via button mashing, and it feels at times like they add one more and more mechanics like spinning white noise and scanning just to pad things out. I guess it's to add more to the actual game play section of the game, but I'm not sure it really adds anything beyond annoyance. Whilst the Ingirisugo translation is mostly good, it does make a few bits in the trials very difficult to understand, some of the logic bullet sections I was completely stumped and had to trial and error my way through as I don't think the translation quite carried what was being said. The comic sections at the end of the trials, whilst cool also suffered from some of the icons being far too small and abstract to actually see what was on them, which was a blemish on an otherwise cool section. I also don't understand why, if you fail in a trial, everyone will turn on you and vote you as the killer. It only makes sense in the first trial, although admittedly it gets pretty funny when it happens right at the end. 

Those issues aren't deal breakers though, I enjoyed this and I recommend it as long as you are ok with anime and a lot of reading...  which if you are reading this you probably are, so go ahead.

146931770.review:
Visual novel where you solve multiple mysteries, including murder. Mostly reading and using logic, but there are some elements that require more active participation unlike the Ace Attorney series. I recommend looking up anything about this game before you play it since it is easy to get spoiled and therefore I will not talk too much about the story or setting. It is a fairly old game, but holds up well. The style is not annoying and the OST fits. The game is a port from PSP and some of the menus/actions could have been optimized for PC, but it works just fine for the type of game it is. I played with japanese voice and english text, and the voice acting is as expected.

The greatest thing might be that you can understand alot more than you first think if you pay attention early. There were never any segments that require moon logic or brute force. The game gives some generous hints, but not too many. 

TLDR; Edgy Ace Attorney with some DDR (rythm). Recommended for people who enjoy detective/mystery games. I think it is worth it at full price, but it is an even better deal at a sale

TRIAL 1: [spoiler] the first trial in the franchise and honestly, pretty disappointing. The culprit is obvious and the motive is weak. 145734202.review:
[b]PERSONAL RATING:[/b] 9/10

[b]GRAPHICS:[/b] Interesting, colour-poppy, and eye-catching. The 2D character models on 3D backgrounds and how they incorporated that was actually pretty cool. Character models have a lot of fun variety, ranging from pretty average little dudes (Makoto and Toko), to conventionally attractive model-types (Junko and Sayaka), to genuinely unconventional and unique (Sakura, Hifumi, Mondo, Hiro, Celeste... honestly, most of them have some unique visual trait about them). The colour scheme and pink blood gives the whole thing a kind of bubblegum splatterpunk vibe that I'm super into.
[b]CHARACTERS:[/b] Great range of personalities, and their different 'Ultimate Talents' lends some more differences between their backgrounds. You have the fashionista model, the jock, the stoic one, the prep, all those cliches - and then they often turn out to be nothing like you'd expect from those cliches. My personal favourites were Byakuya and his smug assh*lery, Chihiro and his sweet timidity, Sakura and her iron moral code, and Leon and his absolute belief in his own charisma - though I also grew oddly fond of Hifumi after playing through his School Mode route before anyone else's.
[b]DIALOGUE/WRITING:[/b] Everyone kind of acknowledges this can get pretty wacky, and, I mean, yeah. There's a talking robot bear who sometimes speaks aloud in emoticons for the hell of it. Don't take it too seriously and you'll probably have a fun time. The plot twists are genuinely great if you go in at least partly blind like I did - I knew Junko would have some greater significance (can't really avoid that with how ever-present she is online) and I kind of got the general gist as to what that significance would be, and I was able to figure out some cases fairly easily, but others caught me genuinely off-guard, and it was super fun to play through them with my fiancee watching me as we both tried to guess what would be revealed.
[b]GAMEPLAY:[/b] It's a visual novel, so expect a lot of clicking, a lot of reading, some dialogue options, and not a lot of physical gameplay. I enjoy visual novels, so the gameplay was enjoyable for me.
[b]MULTIPLAYER:[/b] None.

[b]Favourite Male Character:[/b] Byakuya, [spoiler]Chihiro[/spoiler], Leon
[b]Favourite Female Character:[/b] Sakura
[b]First Character I Liked:[/b] Byakuya
[b]Favourite Character Design:[/b] [spoiler]Mukuro-as-[/spoiler]Junko (it's the freckles!)
[b]Favourite Scene:[/b] The (true) ending
[b]Least Favourite Character:[/b] Probably Toko

145430666.review:
Alright, listen/read. I won't be brief and won't sugarcoat anything. [DOES NOT CONTAIN MAJOR SPOILERS! CONTAINS USEFUL INFO AND TIPS!!]

My Rating: 9.8/10 

Here's Why:

Overall, Dgrpa is an amazing series of games for those that wish to 'step it up a notch' with something unusual and original in the fields of genres like murder mysteries, psychological thrillers, 'whodunnit' uncovering and the overall unique vibe of 'wow, how am I not dead yet?' that all Dgrpa games I've played so far have, both by myself and with friends. 

Now, Dgrpa THH itself did not disappoint, as the unique storyboard and major plot twists absolutely blew my mind. It's so clever, and so interesting. The suspense of 30+ hours of game-play that lead to the last class trial [and what happened in hat class trial, which is just wow] was totally something I never would have expected if I hadn't seen the anime first [more on that in the 'tips' section].

As for the characters, that's an entirely different category of 'holy crap, wow'. It's crazy how all these different characters, with some of them having useless abilities [like, really? Ultimate Fanfic Creator?] can form such an interesting story and keep you glued to your screen without realizing you've become addicted to it. [Also, don't get mad or fret if you see your favorite character getting killed. This is Dgrpa. It's bound to happen sometime.]

In conclusion, the story was captivating and unpredictable, the characters very interesting and unique, the story well-made and packed with interesting little touches, and the world building kept me on my toes the entire time. The occasional long monologues and dialogues can become a little boring, and some things are predictable, but the suspense and intrigue of it all is worth every cent and every minute. 

-------- TIPS!!! --------

1] I don't recommend watching the anime before playing the actual game, as lots of things are different, and rightfully so for 30+ hours of game-play need to fit into 13 20-minute episodes. However, really took away some very interesting and intriguing details and parts of it that are super worth it. I'm getting into the Future Arc now, so I'll probably write about that as well.

2] The game contains constant flashes and bright colors, and I don't remember if there was a feature to turn that off, so that's a MAJOR EPILEPSY WARNING!!.

3] Play the game in Japanese. Please. The original voices are so much better than the dub. [If you pick 'Japanese' as a language when it lets you, it won't change the lettering, and only will change the audio to be Japanese when the characters speak.]

4] Before making any major mistakes, or if you feel like you need to, look up a Walkrthrough. It does help a bunch. [I'm putting links to that later on.]

5] For gift-giving, check the lists of what each character likes most online. The Mono-Mono machine is valuable! Use the points you get from Class Trials and exploring to get items to give each character and improve your relationship with them.

6] Use headphones. It doesn't need much explanation. It's just much better with headphones on.

7] THE GAME HAS NO AUTO SAVE FEATURE!!!! BEFORE YOU LOG OFF ALWAYS MAKE SURE TO SAVE YOUR PROGRESS!!!! YOU"RE GOING TO REGRET IT DEEPLY IF YOU'VE BEEN PLAYING FOR TWO HOURS AND THEN LOSE IT ALL.

-------- WALKTHROUGHS --------

CHAPTER 1:

Hope this helped. Enjoy!

145348478.review:
I really don’t know how to feel about this game. I think half of it is really great, and half of it is really terrible. But do I recommend it? Maybe? Let me go over everything first.

Pros:
I enjoyed free time. I thought traveling around the school was kind of annoying when trying to look for people, but you can just teleport places using the map so it’s not a huge deal.
Chapters 2 and 4 were really great. The focus on the characters and their dynamics in these chapters easily made these the high points of the game.
Most of the characters are fine. A lot of them aren’t necessarily anything too special but I never found at least most of them to be super annoying or anything.

Cons:
I don’t like the premise. It seriously sounds like something I would come up with as a 12 year old. And it was very similar to something I came up with as a 12 year old so there is that. 
Chapters 1 and 3 are dumb. Chapter 1 I can mostly excuse because in games like this, first cases are always usually pretty whatever, but chapter 3 is one of those chapters where everyone acts like idiots for the sake of the plot and the villain was completely obvious from the very beginning.
I don’t like the ending. I’m not gonna spoil what happens at the end for those who don’t want spoilers, but my god was this reveal incredibly lame. I actually enjoyed chapter 5 quite a bit but the payoff to it was not executed well. Also, this is a minor point but the final takedown felt like it came straight out of a pokemon mystery dungeon game, which is also a series by chunsoft. huh.
The gameplay can be… iffy. I don’t hate most of the gameplay or the minigame focus in comparison to similar franchises. What I do hate is the constantly moving text and white noise of Nonstop debates, and pretty much everything about bullet time battles. Seemingly the more they add onto the gameplay, the worse it gets.

Overall, I didn’t hate my time with this game but it has a lot of problems with it. I can see justifying 20 bucks on it. It will hold your interest for what that’s worth, but I just don’t know if this game is for me. Now would I recommend it? I still don’t really know. I’ll mark my review as positive because I did mostly enjoy my time with it, but be mindful of the problems with it before picking it up.

145313486.review:
Tanga rota. Nunca supe como se escribe (El nombre de mi acceso directo)

[h1] Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc [/h1]

Digamos que estuve buscando jugar cosas nuevas porque solo encontraba mas de lo mismo, hasta que alguien me dio la existencia de esta saga y puedo decir que la primera parte aparte de no ser de este tipo de juegos ME ENCANTO.

[b] Resumen para tontos [/b]: Sos un pibe llamado Makoto naegi que ta re feliz para ingresar una academia la cual sus requerimientos es que seas un estudiante y que tengas un talento destacado que te defina en la historia. Digamos que este solo es "afortunado" por entrar de suerte, pero al llegar no es como todo parecia ser. Ya que te duermen de forma tan repentina dentro del colegio. despertas re lol en un banco de aula y ahi es donde empieza el comienzo de la historia conociendo los otros estudiantes que le paso lo mismo que a ti y el comienzo de la [b] Desesperacion [/b]

Basicamente un amongus de anime pero teniendo toda las herramientas para engancharte por horas

Debo admitir que como dije anteriormente, no es mi tipo de juegos y al principio no me interesaba mucho. Pero debo decir que para ser un VN (Visual novel) Esta muy completo para captar mi atencion.

Hablemos de los pros y los contras

[h1] Pros [/h1]

-Personajes mayormente todos carismaticos, Para todo los gustos jaja
-Sus minijuegos son entretenidos y te hacen ejercitar un poco tu memoria mental
-Una trama buenisima
-Puedes explorar TODA la academia libremente escuchando su hermoso OST que tiene y ver su arte de como lo hicieron

[h1] Contras [/h1]

-Si eres una persona impaciente o poco pensativa, te vas a agobiar un poco la cual el juego te exigira un poco de tu intelecto. 
-El juego es muy largo lo cual no esta nada mal que lo sea, pero los puntos de guardado aparecen en casi finalizando el capitulo. Lo cual los capitulos son largos, mi consejo es que guardes cada vez por las dudas manualmente. Asi no tengas la probabilidad de empezar todo el cap de nuevo
-[spoiler] Byakuya Togami es un forro [/spoiler]

[h1] Lo Mejor [/h1]

Siempre vas a sospechar o vas a dudar de los demas para que cuando pasa algo, vas a un juicio escolar (Que es tambien el atractivo del juego) y piensas que la tienes re clara. El juego literalmente te dice "No, estas re equivocado" porque tiene muchos plot twist impresionantes que de seguro te gustaria averiguar mas.

[h1] Conclusion y Calificacion [/h1]

Danganronpa su primera parte es Excelente juego/Novela visual que es una carta de amor para los que le gusta los casos y las investigaciones con su caracteristica amigable de Anime. La cual es un sube y baja por los momentos que pasa, te sentiras impresionado, te sentiras triste, te sentiras feliz y un monton de emociones mas

Aqui dejo mi calificacion:

Historia:10/10
Ost:9/10
Personajes:9/10
Gameplay: 9/10 (Bastante bueno para su genero VN) 
Arte 2.5D: 10/10

Resultado Final: 9.5/10

Recomendada por la mismisima Estudiante Khate!

145231055.review:
This review has been hard for me to write because I personally find these games fundamentally unplayable. The class trials are the WORST part of this game which really sucks because I usually love games like this. The first trial is where they teach you the mini-games and the mini-games themselves are fine (excluding the one where you do the manga panels since that one is awful) and I even find them entertaining. The problem comes with the fact that after you finish the first trial you don't get to use any of these mechanics again for about another 4 hours of game play. I don't have enough time to run through the first couple of trials in one sitting so by the time i get to the next trial i barely remember how to do any of the mini-games. Sure there is a help menu but it breaks the flow if i have to load up the manual and remember how to play every single time i want to do it. It also doesn't help that they still introduce new mechanics such as skills and new variables into the mini-games that leave me overwhelmed by information. The skills are especially confusing on your first play-through as you get them quite often and don't know what any of them do until your second trial. Once you do get them they all revolve around stats that are vaguely explained so you'd need to look up a wiki just to see which ones are worthwhile or not. Even with all of these difficulties around the mini-games the trials themselves also drag on for a few hours and are sometimes a slog to get through. Parts of the game feels more like a chore than something fun and it dampens the overall experience.

However Danganronpa has an impeccable story and stunning visuals accompanied by astounding music. The ideas that it explores and the concept itself is extremely interesting and the characters are very well written. Each character is special and different with their designs, attitude, and interactions with one another. I have fallen in love with this game series despite the glaring mechanical issues it has and it is definitely worth playing.

144959863.review:
I spent middle and high school surrounded by Danganronpa fans, during the peak of its popularity. I played and loved Zero Escape. And yet, somehow, I managed to completely avoid this game, almost all spoilers, and the apparently radioactive fandom this has apparently spawned.

I'm so glad I did.

Going through this blind, without any outside biases clouding my judgement, was a phenomenal experience. Even the things I did know through osmosis were obscured enough within the actual plot that even finding out how said things would be revealed was still great. It also made all the deaths hit that much harder.

The gameplay is great, like a more active, dynamic version of Ace Attorney, oozing with style and personality. All the mysteries were a blast to piece together, and none were so out-there to make a reveal feel bullshit. And, I must admit, while I was never crazy about the art style from what I'd seen online, I was very surprised how good it looks in game. Stills really don't do it justice.

If your only exposure to this game is from people saying "cringe" and nothing else, I highly implore you to try it for yourself, removed from all that. I'm very happy I gave this a shot as an adult without bias, because it really is something else.

144644658.review:
Danganronpa is a masterfully crafted visual novel series that takes storytelling, mystery, and suspense to an entirely new level. From the moment I picked up the game, I was completely captivated by its intriguing premise, unforgettable characters, and mind-bending plot twists. This review is dedicated to showcasing the brilliance of Danganronpa and why it's a must-play for anyone who appreciates a unique and thrilling gaming experience.

One of the standout features of Danganronpa is its cast of characters, each designed with depth and personality that makes them feel real. From the confident and enigmatic to the shy and introspective, every character has their own motivations and secrets that unfold throughout the game. As players, we're given the opportunity to form genuine connections with these characters, making every shocking twist and heart-wrenching reveal all the more impactful.

The narrative structure of Danganronpa is a work of art in itself. Split into chapters, each with its own murder mystery, investigation, and trial, the game constantly keeps players on their toes. The balance between the gripping story progression and interactive elements is perfectly executed. As a player, you're not just a passive observer but an active participant in solving the mysteries, which creates a strong sense of immersion and engagement.

And let's talk about those class trials – the heart of Danganronpa's gameplay. These trial sequences are exhilarating tests of deduction, logic, and quick thinking. The incorporation of various mini-games during these trials keeps the experience fresh and dynamic, preventing any monotony from setting in. The sense of accomplishment when piecing together the truth and exposing the culprits is immensely satisfying.

Danganronpa's visual and auditory presentation also deserves praise. The distinctive art style blends perfectly with the game's dark and suspenseful themes, creating an atmosphere that's both visually striking and emotionally evocative. The voice acting breathes life into the characters, adding an extra layer of authenticity to their personalities and emotions.

What truly sets Danganronpa apart is its ability to elicit a roller coaster of emotions. It can make you laugh at one moment and leave you in tears the next. The themes of hope, despair, friendship, and sacrifice are expertly woven into the narrative, prompting players to reflect on the choices they make and the consequences they face.

In conclusion, Danganronpa is a masterpiece that combines intricate storytelling, compelling characters, and innovative gameplay mechanics into an unforgettable experience. It's a game that challenges your intellect, tugs at your heartstrings, and leaves you craving more. If you're seeking a gripping narrative adventure that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish, Danganronpa is an absolute gem that should not be missed.

143142469.review:
The Danganronpa series is a personal favorite of mine, the bizarre whiplashing tone working wonderfully to give it a very unique feel for a mystery thriller. The characters being heavily exaggerated fits with the tone as well, making them extremely memorable, while the slower and more depressing moments lend them the gravitas and reality to make them feel like real people instead of just caricatures. The mystery is incredibly fun to go through and figuring out the cases in the trial sections can require some genuine thought and a lot of A-Ha! moments. 

The series as a hole has a large amount of Stock Anime Tropes (tm) though, so if you get turned off by something being overly weeby you might find it hard to enjoy. If you are a weeb though, how the heck haven't you played this yet?

For a review of the first game in particular, I think it's personally the weakest of the trilogy (though that's still a really high bar). Primarily because I find Makoto dull as a protagonist, especially compared to how extra and full of life the other characters are.

142990456.review:
Danganronpa is a surprisingly good game with some missteps. I came into this thinking it was going to be cringey and it was but past that it had an interesting story, engaging characters, and some good gameplay mixed with odd mechanics (more on that later). Overall my recommendation is that you should get this game on sale and go in with the mindset that it will be not super serious (despite the plot). My second recommendation is that you try out the Ace Attorney trilogy or better yet The Great Ace Attorney: Chronicles for a visual novel with better mechanics, writing, and story.

TL;DR: It's better than I thought but I'd get it on sale or get Ace Attorney instead.

Now for those who are more interested in my opinion lets get into the nitty gritty. Also these thoughts will be very disorganized.

[hr][/hr]
[h1]No spoilers[/h1]

First lets talk about the gameplay. This has typically Visual Novel gameplay plus some free roam walking around environments and the Class Trials which are the main draw of the game. Now the class trials are very interesting because you are hearing everyone talk about their different interpretations all at the same time and you have to catch their contradictions in the act of it.

The idea is solid but the mechanics of it get a bit muddy. In Nonstop Debates you have to aim at yellow highlighted statments which you believe have contradictions. Then you shoot them with the piece of evidence (truth bullet) that explains the contradiction. Now this mechanic I don't really have a problem with but it can be awkward to add shooting mechanics to a visual novel? The other parts of the trial get worse mechanics in my opinion.

Next is hangman's gambit where you have to spell out a word? But like you shoot the letters. It's just weird and is a time waster in my opinion but not out right horrible like the next mechanic. Which is Truth Bullet battles. They put a rhythm game into this visual novel. A RHYTHM GAME! You have to time shooting statements to a beat which changes. Also one of these is required for each trial! The only saving grace is that you can make these easier by setting your action difficulty down (which i didn't) but its still a stupid concept!

Speaking of difficulty lets go over that. There are two types of difficulty. Action and Logic. Increasing action difficulty makes bullet battles much harder and such a pain. Increasing logic difficulty increases the number of truth bullets in nonstop debates which I actually like since you are forced to think about what the contradiction is more. The feeling on getting like 10 different bullets and having to juggle them, while listening to the statements, and figuring out the contradiction is very fun gameplay for me but if that isn't your cup of tea you should turn it down.

Between class trials lies the weirdest mechanic for me. Free time! When your not in a class trial you are able to go around talking to other students and learn more about them. This to me is a cool feature as you get to learn about their backstories but also gain skills you will be able to use in the class trail. The only part I find confusing is the gift system. Using coins you gain through good performance in the trial or finding by interacting with objects you are able to play a coin game to win items. You can gift these items to other students. They will either like or dislike the item. For me this is a really weird mechanic. Like why? It just feel unnecessary. You can skip these free time segments but for me I did them. [Minor Spoiler] [spoiler]Now when you get into the late game with a very small pool of students free time makes less sense. All the remaining students I had already gotten their skill and talking to them during free time didn't give anything new so I just found a pain and skipped it. It's just so weird that this mechanic is here but this is kind of pushed aside for the 2nd half of the game. [/spoiler]

Okay lets get to the other parts of the game: music and writing. Firstly this game's music is pretty good. It's a weird mix of EDM and weird noises but I enjoy it. Its very consistent and sets the tone very easily. I think my favorite songs are from the class trials and the investigation segments. My only compliant about the music is that if you finish an nonstop debate segment quickly the music switches to another song and you won't be able to hear the full song :(.

Writing. This is a hard section and I will probably have to add more in my spoilers section, but this game has bad writing. But that's okay. For me I accepted it was going to have bad writing and let it surprise me if it got better. And it did. Now when I say it has bad writing I am talking about dialogue and narration. Half of the characters feel like caricatures and play into cliches. The other half are actually interesting even if they still are cliched. The dialogue feels like it was written by a first time fanfic writer especially with the main character's internal monologue. But even then I just skipped over the stupid dialogue. What isn't bad writing is the actual trails and story beats. I will say trail 1 & even trial 2 were very easy to solve but form trail 3 onward they were really good! 

Overall to end this nonspoiler section: I think this game is good but has a lot of missteps. For me those missteps did not ruin the enjoyment of the game but if any of these seem like deal breakers to you don't buy this game.


Overall my score is 6.5/10. The reason I wanted to write this review is because I see this game either get lots of hate or lots of love. I think it's more in the middle. Its good but it has a lot of flaws hence a 6.5/10.

142830619.review:
It's okay. 

Danganronpa as a game series is so polarizing in the fact it is simultaneously the best and worst game I have ever experienced at the exact same time. The entire game series follows a simplistic formula that on-paper is fantastic and opens the pathway to literally endless possibilities of character writing, yet in execution (insert a funny Monokuma joke here) they either nail it perfectly or write the worst characters and cases I have seen in my entire life. 

Pushing past the game series as a whole and speaking STRICTLY about THH, it's... fine. It's just fine, nothing more. I can see why some people may adore this game and see why some people may hate it. Personally, it's not my favorite game, but it's not my least favorite either. 

For the first Danganronpa game, Trigger Happy Havoc makes a pretty good statement of the tone the game is trying to go for. I won't talk about the gameplay, as it's a visual novel-- the gameplay is pretty much just clicking and then the occasional trial mini-game-- but more so the character's and the story, or more specifically the writing. 

Trigger Happy Havoc has a writing style that stands out amongst other visual novels as simplistic and easy to understand. Anyone could play this game and understand the characters. There's a reason several teenagers get into this series-- it's insanely easy to get into with pretty fun characters and sometimes soul-crushing writing. Talking strictly on the characters, the main cast is pretty solid with a few stinkers in the middle of it. Comparing THH to the other main three games, I think it has a pretty okay cast. Not at all the best but not at all the worst. Each character serves the purpose they are given pretty well and are all somewhat fun to look into and watch throughout the tragedy that is the main killing game. All of them have at least a little bit of depth to their actions and words.

With that being said, though, the main premise being a killing game means a lot of characters are going to die off before they can really shine. If I have any singular complaint with this series, it's the death placements. I'll avoid spoiling who dies where, but god, THH sucks with these placements. The characters that should have died ended up living and the characters that should have lived ended up dying, and I don't think that's just my bias against some characters speaking. The game sets up these interesting character arcs and then slaughters the character in cold blood before any value can be gained from them. I hate it.

BUT, with that being said, when a character truly gets their time to shine, they SHINE. This typically happens in the ending or during specific murder cases, and god there are some moments in this game I literally will never forget. 

TLDR; The characters are either really annoying and bad or really good and entertaining. For this game, it's extremely mixed. 

As for the story and the cases themselves, they are simply... okay. 
I think as a general note first, you shouldn't walk into Danganronpa thinking of it like a murder mystery. Sometimes the killer or victim is very obvious. I almost quit the game on the first case because it was so obvious, but that isn't the point. The point is to tell a story, and... well it's DEFINITELY a story! Haha. 
I haven't indulged in many games like Danganronpa, so I won't comment on the quality of the cases themselves too much, but I enjoyed them. Sometimes they're a little too complex or a little too simple, but I always had fun figuring them out (aside from one case. You know what you are). The emotional value of a case hinges on the characters, and like I said previously-- sometimes they end up incredible, sometimes I wish I didn't play the game.

To try and summarize to the best of my ability,
It's okay. It has some really good moments and some really bad moments, but is very fun overall. I personally think the highs make up for the lows. I'd recommend this, if not for this game, at least so you can start the series to play the infinitely better second game. 

Seriously Goodbye Despair is so much better it's actually unreal, but we'll get to that review another time <3

142749769.review:
(I know Steam says I only have 10 hours on this game. I promise you, I've finished the entire main story in the form of a YouTube playthrough, and the 10 hours on here are a replay.)

As a connoisseur of death game media, I was really into the Danganronpa series when I was younger. Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc was the second game I ever got on Steam, my first ever visual novel, and - for better or for worse - I think it will always hold a place in my heart.

...But honestly, the plot of these games is a mess, the mystery isn't really engaging once you realize the characters can and will just pull things out of their ass mid-trial, and the characters themselves are little more than tired old anime tropes with nothing new to add to the table. As I've branched out and read more visual novels, I've realized that there's so much more this genre has to offer.

Want a seemingly tropey cast that [i]actually[/i] has more depth under the surface? Play Doki Doki Literature Club, it's free. Want engaging murder mysteries that give the player all the clues to figure the answers out for themselves? Play the Ace Attorney games. Want a well-written death game story? Your Turn to Die is free, the Nonary Games are two full-length games for the price of one (VLR alone being about twice the length of a Danganronpa game, actually!), and Raging Loop - though this one costs more and is far from perfect itself - is just an overall better-written and way longer experience that does a lot of what I wish DR did with its characters, and even has multiple branching paths.

Speaking as someone who used to love this series to death: there is nothing the Danganronpa games have to offer that hasn't been done better by a different visual novel. Get yourself a better game with this money, or just play a free one.

142723242.review:
This game has many flaws but it's definitely worth checking out due to how weird it's, and how compelling the setting and concept is.

The story is very engaging and makes you interesting in knowing what's going to happen next and solving the mystery of the place you're trapped in. The main flow of the story is how the dialogue some time drags with unnecessary - unfunny - jokes or repeating the same information several times which slows the pacing, but this isn't a game destroying flow.

The characters are unique and have different traits and personalities but honestly I don't think I liked most of them, probably only two characters were more interesting than others while many of them felt like they were just there. The cast could have been utilized more in my opinion.

Gameplay is mostly point and click with you exploring the school, talking to people and collecting clues before the class trial which is a bunch of minigames. I enjoyed the visual novel aspect of the game, but the mini games were mixed bags. Some were fun, while others were done pretty poorly and sometimes even annoying.

As a murder mystery solving, I think most culprits were pretty obvious bar one case, but how the murder went on was convoluted in some cases and I don't think you can figure how every murder happened before the information provided to you during the trial. Some vital information and debates are mentioned during the trials and not during investigation, which makes figuring 100% of the case very difficult, but it doesn't mean you can't at least see the wide picture of the murder or figure certain aspects of it before the trial.

This is a solid visual novel game with a very interesting plot and weird but compelling setting that will want eager to see the end of it and discover the mystery of what's going around you. You won't be able to put this game down till you figure everything for yourself, and for that reason alone, this game is very worth it on any sale.

142675853.review:
Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is an anime visual novel where you must solve murder cases in a high school setting. 

The game's main gameplay is figuring out the mystery, talking with the other students, and doing the trials. I definitely recommend going into this game blind as the story of this game has a LOT of twists that make it a very interesting story and one that definitely should be experienced blind.
I ended up liking most of the characters, as they each have their own charm and things that make them unique, but some just arent very interesting or funny.
The game also contains lots of fan service, with a dedicated mode where you can take any character on a Trip and basically spend a day with them and get to know them. Its fine for those who like that sort of thing but it is required to play through this mode a minimum of 3-4 times in order to get 100% which can take a while to do.

Problems with this game include Trials 1 and 3 feeling "weak", the noticeable amount of fanservice, and although not directly related to the game the fanbase is absolutely wild and definitely should be avoided. 

All around a pretty fine murder mystery game that I enjoyed playing, recommend it to any fans of games like Ace Attorney. I would pick it up during a sale along with the other 2 games in the series.

142351342.review:
I would have absolutely loved this game, if not for the final plot twist. [SPOILERS AHEAD]

Throughout the game I was continually ruminating over the central question: "Who's behind the killing game? What's the reason behind this seemingly pointless suffering?"

I had a few theories—maybe each character is actually a representative of an entire nation, and the school acts as an arena for the world's most powerful nations to resolve conflict in an altruistic way, pitting single representatives against each other so that ten people die instead of ten million.
Or maybe it's some sort of Maze Runner-esque plot, where a seemingly unrelated societal problem can be solved by inflicting despair on these high-school kids.
Since everyone's memories had likely been altered, maybe other things about conscious perception had been altered as well, and "people killing each other inside a high school" isn't at all what's happening in reality.

I was so, so disappointed to find out what the actual answer was—this seemingly pointless misery is being inflicted on these characters because there's someone who loves inflicting pointless misery. It's literally just an insane sadistic person living out their fantasy.

Perhaps this game was worth playing, if only to get to the sequel games. Once you get past the first game's dumb premise, the second & third games are pretty enjoyable. And the beginning and middle of the game were very enjoyable for me.

If you or someone you know has sadistic tendencies: first off, I'm sorry, that sounds rough, but you'd probably enjoy this game with a central theme of "hope vs. despair". It wasn't really for me though.

141902223.review:
This game starts okish but just goes to an absolute crap.
For those who don't know, this is a murder solving game. The initial setup and mystery are quite interesting. That's what keeps someone playing until the end, but trust me it's not worth it.

The gameplay is very weak, you don't get to actually solve most of the case, but instead use the clues to find contradictions while the solution reveals itself. There's very little thinking in most questions.

The characters are all high schoolers but they behave like spoiled children. The dialogue is so boring and repetitive (they remember the same things 3-5 times) that after the third chapter I skipped 70% of it and still got the story. The characters background is also not explored with one exception <spoiler> (kyoko) </spoiler>, nor provides anything interesting in any way.
The target audience appears to be teenagers, but the gruesome parts don't allow for such an age rating. I don't know where the good reviews are coming from. It's also themed around <spoiler>brutal murdering with nonsensical means</spoiler> which reveals something wrong with the head of the guy who came up with this.

The motives make absolutely no sense to a sound person as they are based on the word of a mastermind they all blindly believe, even though they clearly state multiple times it could be fake and it's just to create confusion and paranoia.
Also it appears the mastermind has a lot of power with very advanced tools, but none of it is anywhere in sight, before or after use. Sometimes you have the opportunity to investigate something that would expose a part of the plot but the game does not allow you to for absolutely no reason. After a couple of chapters, everything becomes very basic and all that technology is not used.

The ending is probably one of the worst endings in game history. I still can't believe I played 20 hours to see this. It doesn't answer 80% of the questions and leaves you to imagine the rest.

This game deserves a 1/10 really...

140938457.review:
I have played 90%~ of the Ace Attorney series(all but Edgeworth inv 2, and I have just started on Laytons AA collab game) as whole to clarify and it will and has affect my Opinion on this game.
Gonna just be a quick messy overview.

Starting with the negatives
 The game is alright, it has some clever and interesting cases but the game pretty much plays and solves itself, Its kinda like AA: Dual destiny's in terms of handholding which ruins a lot of the self satisfaction.
So if you expect a good "it can be anyone mystery" it really doesnt feel that way
Case 3 is a good example, its really really predictable almost reaching tutorial case level and just ruins the potential of the characters in it and (note if your good at implying this will be soft spoilers maybe) sucks cause I knew full well how the entire case was going to go at the first obvious character break. Its so painfully obvious and I did not enjoy the case remotely even though I liked the characters I expected something more... IDK well thought out instead of a half assed attempt
 I think the final case, with one of the characters.. Its hard to explain without spoiling, but makes the entire story feel really fucking stupid IMO like cartoonishly stupid.
 Also very predictable twist for the murder case that is so obvious, but its still a solid case for a few aspects that make up for it.
 It also has a very hostile and toxic community in many many areas of the internet that clearly hate the game and the creator saying some of the most vile thing about both, but still try to act like the game is their entire personality. Im unsure about steams community for it but generally they seem chill with only a few of those hostile mouthbreathers here and there.
 The case trial mechanics are just all around unfun and awkward IMO, I like the idea but really it feels.. its just not good with many unpleasant aspects. Though I do like the idea of having skills you can learn, thats wildly unique.

 But for the good aspects of this game:
 Character breaks are cool but not because while its true characters would act a bit different if they are the killer, it just  spoils who the killer is but hey thats in itself in kinda neat I guess.
 At the end of the case their is a comic book "Brain Blast" so to speak kinda like the dumb auto solving box clicking in AA Dual destinies / SoJ but its actually good and doesn't kill the vibe of the game and usually cute art. 
 The twists are mostly pretty solid, a few of them genuinely are surprising either because you refused to believe a certain possibility or just kinda wild.
 Cute/cool characters with unique personalities and all but 1 of 16 of the students are likable, also nice art sprinkled in that gives good service to them a bit, personally I like the Gambler Ultimate though she should be called the 'Queen of fumbling' but honestly I really do like them all barring the one I wont name.
 Interesting concept, while its overall a self defeating aspect, the idea of making fun characters and trying to make you like them even though you know all of them are going to die is done as good as it probably could have been.
 The vibe is cool, you definitely feel the MCs optimism rub off a tad on you,
 Oh yea, the text changing to match what has happened is REALLY cool and gives a feeling to check every single interact able every case or so just to see the new lines. Even a sad moment at the end if you check a certain door, small but you can feel that the devs genuinely cared.

TLDR, its a handholdy mystery detective game that while is predictable at times and for 1 case awful, its not as amazing as AA ofc, but it holds its own enough to where it can still be played and enjoyed for its concepts and pretty solid twists and all around amazing cast of characters. 

 If I had to rate it relative to itself, maybe like a 7.7~ depending on my mood and its probably better to rate each case.
1: 8, Tutorial case, good you can see the twist coming at a certain point but great for entry case non the less.
2: 8.4, phenomenal this one "surprised me" not a true surprise but its one that I didnt want to believe until you have proof even if you can narrow it down early.
3: 5.5, (once again soft spoilers) I knew how this was going to go from the start from 1 out of character outburst and it felt very awkward, the plan was also stupid that only idiots could fall for it. You expected something more from all characters involved in this case.
Many many details tip you off on this case, the sweat, the character breaks, the nonsensical events, ruling out the impossible so only the truth remains and it could ONLY have gone this way. Its almost like what NOT to do when making a case.
4: 8, very Solid though some aspects are predictable, it felt fine all around with some red herrings. Victim was also a fun character and made the case very interesting.
5: 8.2 somewhat predictable, though I really like how it turns out and gives me AA vibes to trust your client and Edge-worth, ontop of an expected twist but this case is also amazing.
6: 7.5 Very predictable to the point I figured all the core aspects of the murder pretty much right off the bat, the twist is so obvious it hurts but with that said and the 1 horrid character has a funny portrait while talking but idk bad bad bad motive reveal IMO, I still liked this case as it felt fun and has a lot of time with some of the the best characters in the game. More fun in the investigation than the trial.

140936041.review: I went into this game completely blind. I didn't know what the basic premise of the game was going to be (other than murder mystery) or how the game was going to flow. As a result, the shock factor of the events that transpire were very impactful onto me as a player, and I think that's what this game is best at. As the first game in the series, it is able to surprise first time players and instill unsettling emotions unlike they have ever felt before. The atmosphere is probably the scariest out of all the danganronpa games, being the claustrophobic, strangely lit, and ominous school; and I feel like the other games have not been able to capture this feeling as well with its settings. However, I think the game relies a bit too much on this and doesn't quite age well as the series progresses, especially to fans who already know all of the surprises danganronpa has in store. The cases aren't quite as extravagant as cases in later games and none really stood out to me as particularly amazing. I still think they are all very good and fun at worst, but not quite up to the quality of the later games. The cast of characters is also mediocre to decent for me, aside from a few standouts like Kyoko Kirigiri (who is the best character in the series change my mind). It is for these reason that I think THH is the worst out of the 3 main games. I must stress though that this game works great for a first time playthrough and I definitely had a positive experience with the game.

140373914.review:
Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is often regarded as a great game for several reasons. Here are a few key factors that contribute to its popularity and acclaim:

Unique Concept: Danganronpa offers a distinctive blend of visual novel storytelling, murder mystery, and courtroom drama. The game sets itself apart by trapping a group of talented high school students in a deadly game, where they must solve murders and uncover the truth to survive. The concept of a killing game with intense psychological elements and a twisted storyline is both intriguing and captivating.

Engaging Characters: The game features a diverse cast of characters, each with their unique personality, backstory, and "Ultimate" talent. These characters are well-developed and often have complex motivations and secrets, making them intriguing and relatable. Players can form attachments to their favorite characters and become emotionally invested in their fates.

Gripping Storyline: Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc has a gripping narrative that keeps players on the edge of their seats. The game combines suspense, mystery, and unexpected plot twists to create a compelling and unpredictable storyline. As players delve deeper into the mysteries of the school and the motives of the mastermind, the tension escalates, making for an immersive and thrilling experience.

Engaging Gameplay: The gameplay in Danganronpa revolves around investigation and trial sequences. Players must gather clues, interrogate suspects, and participate in intense courtroom debates to uncover the truth behind each murder. The trial segments feature clever logic puzzles and gameplay mechanics, such as shooting contradictions with truth bullets, adding an interactive element to the storytelling.

Stylish Visuals and Soundtrack: Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc boasts a visually striking art style with colorful and eccentric character designs. The game's aesthetics, combined with its atmospheric soundtrack, create a unique and immersive atmosphere that enhances the overall experience.

Replay Value: The game offers multiple branching paths, hidden content, and alternative endings, encouraging replayability. Players can uncover additional details, explore different character interactions, and experience different story outcomes, adding to the game's longevity.

Overall, Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is praised for its innovative concept, well-developed characters, engaging storyline, interactive gameplay, stylish visuals, and replay value. It successfully combines elements of mystery, drama, and suspense, making it a standout title in the visual novel genre.

139513416.review:
Amazing adventure style detective game. It's pretty linear, but the story along with it's twist, and the sense of mystery throughout is intriguing. 

Very dialogue heavy, almost like a visual novel, but the characters are genuinely enjoyable to listen to and interact with. The use of the 3D sections for the point and click style gameplay was great for allowing general exploration, adding depth to the high school location and was used well for the information gathering you have to do before trials.

Then the trials act as final boss puzzles where you have to use all your gathered knowledge to identify the killer. The difficulty curve of the trials was pretty good, although you can mostly brute force your way using trail and error, so they aren't too hard overall. The best story progression happens in these though.

139429089.review:
PLEASE PLAY THIS INSTEAD OF WATCHING THE ANIME, THE GAME IS LIKE 20 HOURS LONG AND THE ANIME TRIES TO CONDENSE THAT INTO 12 EPISODES. 

Obviously, you don't have to do that, but the anime is incapable of providing the depth and atmosphere of really being in this school and having to survive a death game and the dopamine of being Makoto and getting a smug sense of satisfaction as you break down lies and misunderstandings and slowly but surely cause the truth of a case to become clear.

DR1 is an extremely fun murder mystery game with a lot of lovable characters, make sure to get as attached as possible to them as the game progresses! Most of the game is VN segments with the class trials consisting of the actual super satisfying mystery solving gameplay. You'll mostly be provided a "gun" loaded with "truth bullets" and you'll use them to shoot down golden colored text in statements that could present weak spots in an argument or lies, and by doing that, you'll reveal a contradiction and further progress the story, and as the class trials keep going you'll get more minigames around figuring out a word, arguing with an extremely pissed person, and finally concluding the case by making a timeline. DR as a series excels in making everything about the presentation of shooting down others arguments appealing. The vfx, the voice acting from Makoto, the presentation, it's all there and it's gotta be one of my favorite feelings from a video game, just calling someone out on their obvious bullshit. 

I really love the cast and how they're probably the most dysfunctional of the all the games. They're selfish and rarely consider you which leads to constant hilarity as Makoto is always getting thrown under the bus while talking about how important it is to work together. All of the cast except Hifumi are likable, and have many various talents that you may see yourself in, providing an easy way for you to end up eventually sad when they die horribly causing you to try and find a new character to replace that hole to lose them again. This is the fun of DR along with the looming fear of despair, so don't fear! Get invested and get ready to DESPAIR. These games rely on their characters, so if you end up not liking any of them or most of them, you're definitely going to have trouble trying to press on. If you feel moderately or poorly about a character, try providing them at least one FTE to see a bit more of how they truly act, you might really like what you see. DRs at its best when you've got multiple favorites, IMO.

Now when it comes to where DR1 is lacking... 
The pacing is a bit odd, there's not a lot going on in most of the chapters and that may cause a bit of boredom or aimlessness as you explore the school, they definitely could have added more events going on per chapter. 

The character screentime management is a bit poorly handled, and the game isn't exactly great at providing you the right characters for the right moments or devoting more time to some of them. Too much of DR1 relies on you managing to "pick right" for the chapter to really hit like it should. I will not further elaborate but hopefully you'll understand what I mean as you play it.

And finally, the stupidity of the characters in some class trials is really obnoxious and not at all entertaining. It's a bit frustrating to have characters not only contribute nothing, but then openly tell you they're useless or sidetrack the trial with their stupid side-tangents. A bit of it is fine but it can get really annoying when you're trying to focus on the serious discussion is going on and someone causes a debate with a statement that everyone should obviously know is incorrect. 

Regardless, DR1 is a fucking WEIRD game that I love with all my heart and was very happy to play for my friend. It's a bit rough, but it's a pretty good showing for the first of a series.

137584463.review:
I like how well balanced this game is with the different gameplay styles it has. It's a VN with social deduction elements just like the Ace Attorney franchise, and it's mainly composed of 3 "Phases" that repeat in all chapters, which are: 
Free time, where all the story set-ups happen
Investigations, where you gather clues
Class trials, where you work alongside the other students to deduct who is guilty in a continuous debate, in which you have to point out contradictions based on evidence you've gathered (very similar to AA games). There are also very simple minigames to mix things up like rythm games.

In terms of difficulty I found it to be quite easy if you pay attention, even in the hardest settings so it's not really a challenging game.
The story is pretty good, I really enjoyed all the developments although some plot twists are kinda obvious, it makes the story lose a bit of strength when you have to play with the characters being all clueless while you have already figured stuff out, but that will change from person to person.

One thing I didn't like at all was the ending, while it's very well thought out and there's a lot of foreshadowing so it's not an ass-pull, they start going in circles over and over to the point where it gets really tiring and it really takes away from the experience, but honestly, all the story until that point makes up for it and that's why I consider it's worth giving it a try.

137041777.review:
I know im late to the party, but I never thought in all my years I would ever play this game. I heard so many things about this game that were so good, but was never interested in playing it. And with enough motivation, holy cow. I gotta say. This. game. Is absolutely a masterpiece.....From start to finish this game straps you in for an amazing ride. With interesting story telling, unsolved mysterious, crime-scene detective work, and hour-long trials where you become your own lawyer. This game has the knack for wonder, the writing of an artist, the mystery that sucks you in and the best part about it. Is the fact that the longer you play, the better it becomes and the more you wanna know, what in the hell happens next?!?!? The art is so unique and brings life out of each and every character, the music is electric and groovy and never. gets. old. The characters in the game actually make you care for them and lastly the effort and the work that are put into this game. Also shows, and for that my friends I gotta say " well ****ing done, I salute you ". Even after you are done with the game there is still so much to do, as there is side bonuses like: Character art/music tracks/re-playable cut-scenes/NG"What if?" mode and much, much more. 

Now word of advice is this.....I know that the gameplay can look. or be. Fairly boring, as it is a " point and click " game. So my best recommendation is to take each chapter into small bites, as well as realize the fact that the game is all "build up" and progressively gets more interesting the deeper you are into story. But when it comes down to it, you gotta realize that it is a visual novel. Which it is to say that the writing, character development and story are peak here and trust me...You will get your moneys worth. 

Note: Advice from a nephew to avoid spoilers for this game and its series. This game/fandom is spoiler heavy so the best way to avoid spoilers is to never type the name of the game. Anywhere. Never read off game reviews. Dont go on Youtube comment section. As well as skip the cutscene everytime you play the game until you beat it.

136586284.review:
Kids are trapped in a high school and told they have to kill one another in order to escape.  

Pros: 
The mysteries themselves (which resolve in six class trials) are pretty good, in that they're largely fair-play.  By the time the class trial starts, you have the necessary info, and you can draw conclusions and figure out who the guilty party is.

The games in the class trials (word-bullet games, an occasional hangman-type game, and a final comic book type game, where you put together the string of what happened) are entertaining.  There's one game (Moment of Truth) that pointless and aggravating, but the rest of the class trial games are decent enough, at least in concept.  The execution of the games leaves something to be desired, but you get the hang of it as you play.

Cons: 
Too much repetition.  Every day starts and stops with that stupid evil bear greeting you with the same phrases, letting you know it's day or night.  And every time you enter a room, the cutesy graphics kick in (i.e. all the furnishings and people drop/spring/slide into place) before you can continue.  Also, the post-trial segments (dealing with the guilty party) go on interminably long. And in between, you're often left wandering a large school, hoping to find something to move the story forward.

The characters: Most are bland or just unlikeable.  Only a few are interesting enough that I cared whether they lived or died.  Most of the girls are cute, though. 

The non-trial segments: During actual investigation segments, there are at least things to do. But there's also a lot of time in the game when you're just wasting time until the next thing happens.  So you can wander around the school, looking for coins to buy random items to give to your classmates, or you can talk to people and try to get closer to them.  I think you're supposed to be developing skills for the class trials when you talk to your classmates, but IDK. Mainly,  it comes across as a bunch of filler time to make the game longer.

As I write this, the game is getting 'Overwhelmingly Positive' reviews, so maybe I'm missing something.  But for me, the ratio of time investigating/solving mysteries vs. the time doing nothing in-game is just not good enough compared with other mystery games I've played, and there's not enough else in the game to make it worthwhile.

135984620.review:
I'm writing this now after I've completed every achievement in the game. There may or may not be real tears in my eyes after 70 hours of exhausting all avenues of content. This review is written assuming that you have basic knowledge of the game's premise and some of the mechanics.

I think Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is the best game in this series. From the tone, to the colorful cast, to the fun trial mechanics, and to the story, I genuinely think that there is rarely a moment where this game doesn't shine as a masterpiece of funny yet emotional storytelling.

The gameplay loop exists as a visual novel mixed with social simulator for most of it, with you reading the story and using the protagonist, Makoto Naegi to pursue characters you're interested in and learn more about them. It's fun if you're into that sort of thing. Every character presents a unique depth to them, even those that die early, and learning about them feels both rewarding and interesting. Their interactions with Makoto also lend a lot to him as a character as well, as you learn how he thinks of others and how he confronts their faults. Each character in this game is someone you can either relate or connect to, which serves to make their deaths, survivals, despair, and hope all the more captivating. In this cast, there's something for everyone to enjoy.

The trials, though, is where this game really shines. They take a couple of hours, with you analyzing behaviors and evidence to masterfully unravel what happened during each case. I don't have much to say about the gameplay itself other than that it's fun as hell! Seriously, playing the trials is the highlight of any run. And then, at the end of the trial, you witness the execution of the perpetrator of the crime in a beautiful cutscene that serves as a satisfying conclusion to their story. 

Another place where this game shines is the soundtrack. Masafumi Takada did a great job composing for this game. The intro song is a BANGER. Nothing feels out of place or annoying, and when something is high stakes, the music makes sure you feel that tension. Beautifully done.

I will say that this game isn't without its faults. 13 years after release, and there are certainly aspects of the game that aged poorly. The sexualization of teenagers, odd portrayals of mental illness, among some mildly offensive jokes can take the player for a loop. It's not enough to detract from the story, I think, and many fans have expanded on some of the offensive aspects to fit them in a modern lens through fanworks. You should consider it and remain conscious and critical of these things, but there's still room for you to enjoy the story.

There's also a lack of replayability. The story remains the same with only a few alternate cutscenes you can get. I think that the game is still good enough to replay after a while, though, as during my road to 100% Completion I did replay the story after roughly a year since I'd first played it. You get to experience some of the minor moments between characters that you may have forgotten, which gives the game a quality that means you can still come back to it, I think, despite the major story beats not changing.

Overall, I love this game, and I think that you should play it if you can afford it. It's roughly 20 hours to play, and goes on sale quite frequently.

135551217.review:
Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is a deeply, deeply flawed masterpiece.

I both love and hate this game but it is undeniably an incredibly memorable experience.

As someone who feels people who spoil things should be handed to Monokuma for punishment, I am going to give a brief rundown of what I liked and disliked of the game and it will be SPOILER FREE.

I love the art-style of the game, especially the 'pop-up' book style of the scenes and the 2D characters. As for the characters, they are all well drawn and unique in their own way. The music, also is brilliant and the English voice acting I think does a superb job. There should be characters you like, characters you hate and everything in between.

The plot is engrossing, full of twists, turns and more twists. I simply couldn't put the game down and despite the (30+) hours I've put in, it really did fly by. This isn't some 5-hour visual novel, you will really get your money's worth here.

It manages to combine dread with black humour wonderfully and Monokuma is such a lovable yet hateable villian. If I had to compare the game to something, I'd say it's like a much more entertaining version of the 'SAW' films.

So what didn't I like?

The cast is...brainless. If this is Japan's 'best and brightest' then they are in serious trouble. Outside of Kyoko (my favourite character), the entire cast feels exceptionally dim-witted. The first case should make that glaringly obvious to you. But even by the 5th case, when you have to prove one of the cast isn't a ghost (despite them standing in front of you), the low-IQ group just never get any brighter. Painfully obvious things are drawn out and discussed at length by the cast and you WILL be rolling your eyes as you wait for them to figure out the obvious.

You play as Makoto who is a nice-but-dim sort. Expect to have figured out the most basic things long before he has. It's frustrating and, despite the adult nature of the game, it sometimes gives the cases an almost 'detective-game-for-children' vibe to it.

Speaking of the cast, I found the female cast FAR more engaging than the male cast. Now, this is subjective and I know your initial reaction may be "uh-huh, you love the waifu's" but it's more than that. The girls are interesting, unique and quirky: Celeste, Sakura, Kyoko, Toko are all memorable. The guys are like bland, 2D stereotypes. Mondo, Hifumi, Kiyotaka, Leon...they are all just dull to me. Only Byakuya manages to stand out.

Finally, the court-scenes are just a mess. The mini-games are absolutely awful. Poorly explained and just tedious in the extreme. By the time I got to the later cases and the (as I called it) 'Disco-Mode' activates and you have to shoot statements to the beat I was hating the mini-games. They disrupt the flow of the game and break up the narrative of the interesting cases. I have no idea why they thought this was a good idea. I liked the 'comic-book' puzzle and that was it.

I'd recommend you buy Danganronpa to experience it for yourself. It has a plot and voice-acting way above the AAA garbage, it has a memorable cast and a wild story that Kojima would be proud of. However it IS frustrating, tedious and marred by poor design decisions.
