135072398.review:
The way I see it, Danganronpa is a combination of three other popular games:
- Phoenix Wright-style game loop of point-and-click evidence gathering and then selecting the right item during dramatic court debates
- Persona-like social sim where you spend time with your choice of characters to learn more about them and gain new skills
- Zero Escape-style story and themes of desperate death games between a group of strangers-become-friends where the only way out is not to play at all

But the problem is... Dangaronpa sucks in all three of these areas!
- The debates are so easy, they insult player intelligence. In fact, if you do any reasoning on your own, you will have a *harder* time figuring out the right answer, because the game *expects* you to play dumb until you are led into the right hints!
- The social stuff is very limited, there are no fun activities, farming gifts is really tedious, and character development is very shallow. So all this social mechanic is bleak and unrewarding.
- And it terms of the narrative it's ridiculously dumb compared to other games in this genre. The first few chapters of the story follow a set of rules, laws that govern the game world, which you can use to build an understanding of the story. All of that goes way out of the window by the time you reach climax, which turns crime mysteries into traditional anime "good vs evil" struggle based in absolutely ridiculous ideas, like "despair is actually a contagious disease" shit.

And to add to the pile of dissimilarities with the three aforementioned archetype games, the BGM, while not that bad on its own, is nowhere near the quality of Phoenix Wright, Persona or Zero Escape series.
I did enjoy the Japanese VAs, though. In particular, Toko, Kyoko, Monokuma and Byakuya have their voices brilliantly performed.

Finally, I'm confused about the target audience of this game. On one hand, it depicts some of the most gruelsome violence I've seen in VNs - though I admit I'm not too familiar with the horror genre. On the other... the blood in all pictures is neon pink colored, characters talk like kids, and everything's explained like the player is five. I understand Japanese writers' love for some high-school drama, but particularly in Dangaronpa the juxtaposition of adult themes with kids mentality is particularly jarring.... and it doesn't subside as the story progresses.

134943151.review:
Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc es una de las mejores novelas visuales, y dentro de todo con una mecanica fisica jugable, en su genero. Sobre todo si hablamos de suspenso, misterio y buena trama.

La historia, o los hechos, giran entorno a 15(+1) estudiantes de la prestigiosa Academia Kibougamine, donde solo estudiantes Definitivos, es decir aquellos que destacan por sobre los demas en un ambito en especifico, pueden darse el lujo de pertenecer. Sin embargo, la cosa cambia cuando descubren que en realidad es una "prisión" de la que solo podra salir uno, pero con una condición: deberas cometer un asesinato sin ser descubierto. Sumidos en una constante desesperanza y desesperación, tu única misíon es escapar.

Lo primero que me llamo la atención fue la premisa del juego: para que alguien pueda escapar, debe primero cometer un asesinato y no ser descubierto. Siendo algo que acompaña muchisimo al juego es el misterio y lo introducen de una manera tan genuina, que automaticamente nos hacen poner en el papel, de no solo el protagonista, sino tambien del resto de los estudiantes. La manera que tienen de narrar los hechos e hilar las cosas a medida que la trama avanza, me parecio excelente. No hay por donde decir que "es malo". Por lo general soy de esos que abandonan una novela cuando se torna muy pesada en cuanto a dialogos, aun sabiendo que es el punto fuerte de una... yo sé que algunos entenderan de lo que hablo, pero Danganronpa fue todo lo contrario.

Los personajes, con los cuales no familiarizas mucho al inicio, se van desenvolviendo y con esto desarrollandose. No son nada en el final a comparación de las actitudes que adoptaban en un inicio. Considero que es un punto fuerte del juego: sabe como desarrollar a los personajes sin que se vea forzado. Sin contar que te encariñas con ellos xd.

Tiene un visual arte fascinante. Cuando juego algo por primera vez, siempre priorizo el cómo los desarrolladores pueden hacernos llegar, de alguna manera, el cómo se sienten los personajes y para ello me apoyo mucho, no solo en los dialogos, sino tambien en las expresiones. Principalmente en aquellas de desesperación, que es donde más hace hincapie el juego. De hecho se podria decir que tiene un contraste bastante bello con respecto a la desesperación y la esperanza.

Cuando al inicio nombre algo de "jugabilidad fisica", me referia a que por ser una novela visual no todo va a ser un sinfin de dialogos y saltos de escena. De hecho lo compre sin saber, pero el juego te permite pasearte por el mapa, ya que por cada asesinato se realiza un Juicio Escolar, el cual tiene como objetivo descubrir quien es el asesino. Para ello, el juego, y como lo dije, nos permitira movernos por el mapa para encontrar pistas e incluso para afianzar las relaciones con los demas personajes, mediante un sistema de regalos,  utilizando el tiempo libre que nos dan. Esto nos permite ganar habilidades para cada juicio y utilizarlas a nuestro favor

Más allá de ser un juego totalmente surrealista, deja un bonito mensaje que no pasa por desapercibido. Danganronpa es sin duda alguna, uno de los mejores en su genero, y es una joyita que no deberias perderte de probar.

Te recomiendo comprarlo en oferta, aunque tambien lo pagaria por el precio original ya que más allá de ser un poco viejito tiene mucha calidad para ofrecer.

134493971.review:
This game frustrates me. At the end of the day I have to ask, who was this made for? It got rated D in Japan, meaning over 17, and rated M in the states. However, the characters are all high schoolers, very much so. The English translation adds ways too many vulgarities to add to the M rating. If we were to remove these vulgarities, the writing and cases are really really simple to understand and would have been fun as a middle schooler to play....but as an adult, just seem frustrating at how often the same thing is said again and again and again and again. If it were cut down and you actually had to use your brain rather than being led straight to each answer by the hand I'd give it an upvote...but it's just not fun because of how easy it is.
Compared to Pheonix wright games, which were rated T in the states because they didn't go over the top with language and the cases weren't so violent, they were the perfect games to play as a middle schooler....kinda funny how a game with adult protagonists is aimed at a younger audience (or more general audience) than a game with "high schoolers".
Also if you play this game because you like gore, please seek therapy. This world has enough violence and danger in it already, there is no reason to add to it. Especially towards children.
So I'm terrible at making points but I'll try to be succinct:
Tone it down and aim it for middle schoolers...Great.
Or
Make the game harder and make the characters adults?....Also Great

134055007.review:
Danganronpa THH has to be one of the best visual novels I've played that kept me entertained and surprised throughout the entire story. With the amount of twist and turns the story took I couldn't even begin to predict what would happen next for each chapter. The characters are all memorable with each one always offering something to the table, whether if it was how important to the plot & story or how hilarious and mysterious they were.

Beyond this will mainly be about my experience with the endgame content

[spoiler] I also love that after completing the game, you can do endgame content with the cast for a side game where you can get to know everyone that little bit more. This definitely allowed to me to enjoy/remember each character that much more. The game-play itself tho apart from being used to get everyone completed for the achievements, can be very repetitive and boring at times, especially after the first run since all you are doing is grinding materials and holding whatever button it is to skip the process. The extra content with artwork and cut-scenes you can scroll through is a very nice touch, loved going back and watching the punishment times again [/spoiler]

Overall: I would honestly give this game a try and see if it's for you. The story without spoiling yourself is amazing and never felt disappointing to me, definitely worth every penny.

133533129.review: I'm on the fence as to whether or not I should recommend this game, I loved both Zero escape and the Ace attorney Series, so after hearing a lot of praise for the Daganronpa series I figured It would give me something similar. And that's not entirely wrong however, some of the clues to solve certain trials are so obvious it's almost painful to watch the characters run around in circles over and over again waiting for you to point out the obvious sometimes multiple times. Toko and her split personality also have to be one of the most stupid character I have ever ran across in a visual novel, they add nothing to the story [spoiler] and the fact that she is a serial killer never actually comes into play, and I feel like the fact that she is one of the final survivors add more insult to injury, considering characters like Sayaka, Sakura, Kiyotaka and Mondo were way more interesting and died without being fully fleshed out [/spoiler] there's also the fact that for certain investigations you are literally being dragged from room to room by another character removing a lot of agency from the player. Overall I still enjoyed it, but i probably would only recommend this to people who already like visual novels as I'm not sure if this would be a good entry to the genre by itself

de toda la saga es probablemente el 2do peor en jugabilidad (solo siendo superado por el somnifero que es ultra despair girls) pero eso ni significa que sea mala, es extremadamente entretenida al igual que la del 2 y la del v3, simplemente que con los proximos juegos se fue refinando y mejorando, ahora en temas de historia esta me parece la mas balanceada y solida de toda la saga, si bien la del 2 me parece la mejor de la saga, esta es la mas balanceada, ya que si bien en el 2 tenias el capitulo 2 que era facilmente el peor del juego y su final que era muy hit or miss, en este no hubo un capitulo que me disgustase mucho, todos mantienen casi el mismo nivel de calidad, y definitivamente este es el juego de la saga que tiene el mejor final de todos. 
Ya con los personajes si bien varios me gustan hay otros que no tanto, siendo este para mi el juego que tiene al peor personaje de la saga como parte de su cast principal, Junko Enoshima, y hay otros que no me terminaron de gustar mucho (Makoto Naegi, Kyotaka Ishimaru e Hifumi Yamada por dar otros ejemplos), pero eso no significa que todo su cast sea malo, ya que hay otros personajes que me gustaron mucho (Toko Fukawa, Sakura Ogami, Chihiro Fujisaki y Byakuya Togami por dar unos ejemplos). en general este me parece el segundo mejor juego de la saga y probablemente el que tiene el mayor factor sorpresa en lo que viene a ser los casos y plot twists, y en general un juego que esta bastante bueno, no es una obra maestra ni en pedo (hay varias cosas que le quitan varios puntos), pero en general me pareció un juego bastante entretenido.

Recomendado

This game successfully broke and filled me with despair. :,) I love this game and will probably never get over certain characters + how things ended (to be completely honest I was enraged with the games conclusion but after thinking about it more, I'm pretty sure that's exactly what they wanted). 
Some game mechanics were difficult for me to pick up but I got used to it. 133178801.review:
It's just not for everyone. If you REALLY like the concept you will enjoy it. But you have to be interested in this niche theme in the first place. I bought it on sale expecting well written and engaging murder cases to solve (because that's what the fans make it sound like) but the game holds your hand way too much.

It's very linear and predictable. Motives behind each murder case are either obvious, or extremely obviously setting up a twist. Even if you (the player) figure out what happened you still have to sit through a few scenes where the main character is clueless. You don't even need to think to progress. Just follow the instructions and markers and the game will reveal the truth. Honestly, it's quite jarring.

The "social deduction" aspect is also a bit underwhelming because the characters aren't properly fleshed out. Especially the main character whose entire personality is based around being just an average guy surrounded by prodigies. There is the ultimate gambler, the "moral compass", the otaku, the biker gang leader, the pro athlete etc. They all act like what you'd expect from their respective tropes with a few twists.

The character designs on the other hand are really unique. I like this art style a lot. Combined with great soundtrack and voice acting it creates a fitting mood for a gritty murder mystery game.

Unfortunately, if you care about good character writing and engaging cases to solve... just play Disco Elysium.

132882356.review:
I wanted to like this game, because I absolutely loved AI- The Somnium Files....
But...
It starts off interesting enough, but it very quickly becomes ridiculously repetitive- the exact same things are gone over multiple times during a trial, the exposition is absolutely terrible and repeatedly punches you in the face and I found myself fast-forwarding through most of the 2nd half, as I didn't care about the story anymore- I just waned it to end so I could play the next one.
What pissed me off most, was the way the story unravelled - intriguing at first, but it quickly becomes painfully obvious that the writers had nowhere else to go, nothing meaningful to say so they rushed to the end.
There are so many mechanics in this game, and for the most part- they are not utilised well.  It is one thing to under-promise and over-deliver, but that only works when what you over-deliver on is cohesive and fits in with the story and plot. 
Most of these mechanics are drip-fed to you and only succeed in making the game sections annoying and tedious.

I know this one negative review amidst a sea of hundreds of good ones will not be enough to sway you from buying this game, but wait for a sale.
And don't say I didn't warn you

This game was great.

It is very similar to Ace attourney somehow, maybe a little less linear with a few choices and personal relationships with characters you like.

The story was great. Not incredibly complex, but very entertaining and atmospheric.
Same thing with the soundtrack. This game really sounds high quality, even though it is just a port of a psp game. Compared to some other psp ports this one is a very good one.

It is a linear game and it is a lot of reading. Some of the dialogue is also very drawn out or "written for a toddler" so-to-speak as they explain some things over and over again. It should also be stated that this game has a "new game +" so you can experience all the character interactions and play out a different story. A nice addition for those who are interested.

I highly recommend this game. If you like ace attourney don't sleep on this game and grab it. It is worth full price but goes on pretty steep sales every now and again.

131859695.review:
I had first learned about this series when the anime had first come out years ago, which made me check out the games. And I was instantly captivated by it and in fact played it multiple times over during the years, both on Steam and also on Switch.

It was the first time I saw the genre of “killing game”, where a bunch of students from an elite school get trapped and are forced to kill each other to escape. Being a mystery the game of course builds itself on solving the mystery as for why they are trapped in the school and who is behind it all, over the course of the whole of the story. While during every chapter having to also solve a new murder case in so called “Class Trials”.
Admittedly some of the class trials, where you had to solve a murder, were a bit easier to solve than others, but they were all still satisfying to solve nonetheless with the clues you collected over each investigation. However the main mystery of the school, [spoiler]which is that the apocalypse had happened due to society issues with their worship of talent and elite that the antagonised used for their means,[/spoiler] really took me by surprise. But it made sense, because there is a lot of foreshadowing throughout the whole story that lead up towards the final conclusion.

The gameplay and style of the game is also something I really came to enjoy.
Every chapter is split up into “Free Time”, which is basically a novel game where you spend time with the other characters, give them gifts, become friends with them (which gives you special abilities during the Class Trials), and also learn their backstories. “Investigation” that is more akin to a Point and Click style of gameplay, where you have to go throughout the school and collect clues to solve the murder. And finally “Class Trial”, which is a shooter style of gameplay where you have to solve the murder and find out who the blackened is through finding contradictions in what everyone is saying and literally shooting their words with your evidence, among various other quick time events.

But what I think really sells the game, together with the whole mystery of the series, is the cast. Because they are just so incredibly varied and over-the-top fun (which is on purpose, as the game exaggerates to make its point clear). They all have such unique designs, but when you come to know them over the course of the story you learn about their backstories and motivations, which really makes you root for them. Which makes it even more heartbreaking if they then end up dying as either a victim or a blackened.

Also what is worth mentioning is that there is quite a lot of bonus game content that you unlock at the end of the game. The most noticeable being the silly Dating Sim that you can play, to basically get the rest of your classmate's backstories that you didn't manage to get during the main game.

All in all I can only recommend this game.

131797204.review:
[h1]Despair. 9/10[/h1]

[b]Are you into detective novels and only started reading visual novels recently?[/b] Well, this is a huge recommend for you. Trigger Happy Havoc is the first entry of the Danganronpa franchise and a damn great one at that. 

[b]This visual novel is very good.[/b] The story is amazing. It sets up a great mystery that gets you really curious. And when the mystery eventually unfolds, you are pleasantly surprised and the mastermind behind it all is such a great villain. The characters are great, it's pretty easy to like a character and find one to be your favorite. Then, your favorite character dies. Never get attached to any characters in this game, I swear. 

[b]A visual novel is called a visual novel because it's got visuals. This one's visuals are great.[/b] The sprites, character design, the illustrations done for this game are nice to look at. Some of you might already know damn well that this game is famous for its pink blood. Pretty close to red. Oh, and some of you might also have listened to this game's soundtrack before. It's one of the finest I've heard from a game. The soundtrack is a banger and used incredibly well.

[b]A bonus, the gameplay is surprisingly fun.[/b] Daily Life is the first act of the game. It is free roam and you get to choose how to manage your time, you've got many ways to spend your time. You can do Free Time Events, interact with classmates and strengthen your bond with them; you can even gift them presents. You can also find collectibles and collect Monocoins from all around Hope's Peak Academy, or you can just sleep through the day and proceed into the story.
Then, we hit the climax and switch to Deadly Life. You investigate and search for clues and evidence to solve the case. Eventually, after you gather enough evidence, you open the iconic red door. The Class Trials, the last act of the chapter. The class trials have great gameplay mechanics that honestly make the game so much more fun. Not only is the story interesting and entertaining, the gameplay as well helps make the story feel even better. Once you find the culprit, you then get thrown into the final phase of the trial, execution. The execution scenes are BRUTAL. 

[b]Overall, a great game.[/b] The story, characters, art, gameplay: All great. This game also has a large following, so you can talk with other fans about the game once you finished it.

From the creators of awkward dating sim histrionic nightmare teens part 3 and 4 ( I'm sorry, Persona 3 and 4 ) comes that word that's hard to pronounce: Trigger Happy Havoc. Pros (there's alot):
- SUPER entertaining, you really wanna know who dun it

- Now Persona, was lets date and laugh and the worlds ending, this, same thing but, the worlds ending then you date and hope they dont kill you, same thing but different

- The characters, amazing, ya care about em, some are LEGIT interesting, which is weird cuz ya know they're ALL gonna die, and not just the personalities, the voice actors, the, weird faces they make, they did an excellent job with art and voice, I cant say more without spoilers

131058213.review:
Words cannot describe how good this game (and game series) is. Despite the fact that this was the second Dangan game I played (with the first being Dangan Goodbye Despair), with this being the first game in it's franchise, the game gets right to the point with the story and is straightforward. The [English] voice acting was amazing and the character designs/personalities really fit well. The game-play itself is pretty cool. Dangan Trigger Happy Havoc has plenty of content for new players to experience with a decent 20-50 hours, of game-play depending on whether you want to be a completionist or just want to get through the main story. Yes, there are characters that you will LOVE and there will be characters that you wish to BURN ALIVE. But as an overall game, I rate it a 9/10.
!!! However !!!
When playing ANY of the Danganronpa games (not including Ultra Despair or Summer Camp), the game does not jump straight into the murder/class trial stuff... There has to be a story to the game otherwise, it will make no sense to what is happening. Also, the game contains, and is not limited too, swearing, blood/gore (duh), mild sexual content and various other dark themes.

This game is a definitive visual novel. Its only my second time playing one, and its a game to be experienced. The logic is definitely for those who have time to sit down and take notes, but in my book this is a game where it doesn't hurt to use guides. Especially considering the class trials. They are one and a half to two hour long scenes that you cant save during, so you pretty much have to make time for the game. Regardless, its phenomenal. The final trial almost made me throw my controller out the f*cking window after i lost the final strike, but it was at least generous enough to let you retry. Any other trial, if you loose you go right back to your last save. A bit brutal, but well worth my time and money. The ending can be described by the final achievement. Not a total let down or controller smasher, but it definitely could have been better.

Side notes:
-Vaped the equivalent to a pack of cigarettes during the final trial
-Its a game that doesn't really benefit from being on one platform or another, so buy it wherever its cheapest or buy it physically if you're oldschool like me
-F*ck Junko.

130799556.review:
Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is a visual novel-style game with an interesting twist on the trial system. Players join the protagonist Makoto Naegi, who is trapped in a prestigious private school with fourteen other unique and interesting characters.

The game strikes a nice balance within the trials by providing you with enough information to develop a theory of events while still allowing you to be surprised by the outcome. The game is absolutely worth the price point and the interactive visual novel is both entertaining and well written.

The game may start somewhat slowly, but it quickly becomes an exciting experience that is sure to keep you engaged. The game world is vibrant and full of interesting characters, and the puzzles and mysteries you'll encounter along the way are both challenging and satisfying.

The game also offers a spoiler-free strategy guide which is helpful for players who are stuck or want to know what to expect. All in all, Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is an exciting and immersive visual novel that is definitely worth playing.

130662285.review: Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is a game that seriously surpassed my expectations. I have known about the Danganronpa series for a very long time but never got around to actually playing it. In 2023 I wanted to start the year off with something new and this was the perfect game to do it with. The gameplay is fun, the music is fantastic, and the characters are all well-written. Even the characters that I did not like as much were still well-written and brought something new to the table! In my experience, usually, games like this are very predictable and besides a few instances, I was left blindsided nearly the entire time which just proves how good of a narrative this game really offers the player! I will not get into spoilers but there are certain scenarios that were legitimately impressive narrative feats! This game's plot is some of the best writing I've seen in a video game ever! I will admit I was suspicious of this game and series for a very long time but I'm super glad I finally got around to playing it! There really is nothing I can criticize the game for besides nitpicking. I do not usually give this amount of praise to a game, especially this genre of game but it is downright one of the best games I've ever played and I cannot wait to play the next ones in the series! Great job Spike Chunsoft you have created a game that will be remembered as a classic in the genre for a very long time!

130382822.review:
Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc es un juego de aventura y visual novel desarrollado y publicado por Spike Chunsoft. Se lanzó en 2010 y está disponible en PlayStation Portable, PlayStation Vita, PlayStation 4 y PC. El juego es conocido por su intrigante historia y personajes interesantes y es una de las entregas más populares de la serie Danganronpa.

En Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc, los jugadores asumen el papel de Makoto Naegi, un estudiante de instituto que es seleccionado para asistir a la prestigiosa escuela de Hope's Peak Academy. Sin embargo, cuando llega a la escuela, se encuentra atrapado junto con 14 otros estudiantes y se le dice que no podrán salir hasti que maten a uno de ellos y no sean descubiertos. Los estudiantes deben participar en "tribunales" y utilizar pruebas y testimonios para descubrir quién es el asesino. Si lo descubren, el asesino es ejecutado y los demás pueden seguir con vida, pero si no lo descubren, todos menos el asesino son ejecutados.

Una de las cosas más destacables de Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc es su intrigante historia y personajes. Los personajes son únicos y tienen personalidades y motivaciones interesantes, y el juego es excelente en términos de construir tensión y suspense a medida que avanza la historia. Además, el juego tiene una serie de minijuegos y secciones de "investigación" que involucran recolectar pruebas y resolver rompecabezas para avanzar en la historia.

En cuanto a la presentación del juego, Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc tiene un estilo de dibujo animado y una estética visual única. Los gráficos son detallados y atractivos, y la música es pegajosa y bien elegida. Los controles son intuitivos y fáciles de usar, lo que hace que el juego sea accesible para los jugadores.

En resumen, Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc es un juego de aventura y visual novel excepcional que atraerá a cualquier fanático de la intriga y el misterio. Con su historia interesante y personajes bien desarrollados, este juego es una experiencia emocionante y adictiva que no se puede perder. Además, con su estética visual atractiva y controles intuitivos, es un juego que es fácilmente accesible y disfrutable para cualquier jugador.

130373875.review:
OH... MY... GOD... WHAT A GAME! WHAT A MASTERPIECE!
Gameplay: Good. At first I didn't expect too much from this game, but as soon as I saw trial gameplay I said OMG, this is just genious! As always Japanese are really genious at game making, I would never imagine what gameplay involving trial would look.
Story: Good. Really liked the first 3 Class Trials, 3 is far my favourite, and the 6th trial was also good.
OST: That dynamic music that plays when "Make Your Argument!", also Free Time and others are really good OSTs.
Graphics: Really fell in love with that student-project-like simplisistic and basic graphics. You don't even feel the air, and that is what I liked about it, it is like a student made that game, but actually nailed colour selections with kinda cute graphics for school indoors.
School Mode: OMG I played this mode 2 hours straight and didn't feel how fast time passed! Enjoyed every second of it! And the fact that you get every character's pants after fully increasing their heart rate is just hilarious! 
Characters: Celestia Ludenberg, Kyoko Kirigiri, Chihiro Fujisaki (her sad and smug reactions are my fav LOL), Hifumi Yamada (SAAYYYWHAAAA), Aoi Asahina, Junko Enoshima and others. Byakuya at first irritating, but you like him with time, but couldn't love that annoying fujoushi Toko. Would love to hang out with Hifumi, Yasuhiro, and maybe Sakura. I knew all along that the mastermind was [spoiler]Junko Enoshima[/spoiler], but also had a little anxiety and fear that they would turn out to be a boring villain, but to my surprise I really liked them! LIked their every reaction, my fav was king, mighty with crown reaction, they kinda looked like [url=https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=613450737447942&set=a.472014384924912]my main King Puff from Minion Masters[/url]. Plus, those mushrooms when they are sad was hilarious and tasty looking for some reason LOL.

Thanks for the gift, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198129322529]Eric Draven[/url]!

129583343.review:
Oh ho ho, what a conundrum I have found myself in! Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc, a game that has left me with more questions than answers.

First and foremost, let me address the elephant in the room: the characters. My goodness, they are a curious bunch, each with their own unique quirk and motive. But as the plot thickens and the body count rises, I found myself wondering: who can I trust? Is anyone truly innocent in this twisted game of life and death?

The gameplay itself is equally perplexing. On one hand, the "Class Trials" put my logic and deduction skills to the test, as I tried to piece together the truth from the conflicting testimony of my fellow students. On the other hand, the "Free Time" sections allow me to form relationships and uncover secrets about my fellow classmates, further muddying the waters of my own suspicions.

But the real mind-boggler for me was the story. It's a rollercoaster of twists and turns, full of shocking reveals and plot twists that kept me guessing until the very end. Just when I thought I had everything figured out, the game would throw another curveball my way, leaving me scrambling to reevaluate my assumptions.

In short, Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is a puzzle box of a game, one that will keep you guessing until the very end. If you're a fan of mystery and intrigue, then this is definitely a game for you. But beware, dear reader: this game will have you questioning everything you thought you knew.

129563237.review:
[h1]Visual novel part - very solid. Trials? Not so much. Proceed with caution![/h1]

As crazy as the story gets - I liked how it developed. The overall mystery about the events and characters was kept up until the very end of the game - on that part I was hooked. [b]Solely on this, I recommend the game[/b].

The actual trials though - [b]they simply didn't click with me[/b]. Maybe I've had some subconscious expectations (huge Ace Attorney fan), but they felt overdone, with mechanics being unnecessary and annoying. I think part of the problem was me picking a higher difficulty level, which didn't necessarily make the game harder but more irritating due to all the extra stuff not being skippable.

[b]tl;dr[/b]
It's hard to put anything in context without spoiling the game BUT if you are into weird Japanese stuff and solving gruesome murder mysteries involving high school students - give it a go. If actual trials scratch your alley more (again, I'm an AA fan) - make sure this specific approach is okay with you.

129367177.review:
Un juego bastante intenso y que merece ser rejugado un par de veces para lograr completar todo y ver las posibilidades que este mismo nos aporta a lo largo de la historia.

La historia del juego es simple pero interesante, eres un estudiante común que fue seleccionado a base de un sorteo para entrar a una de las mejores escuelas de la ciudad junto a varios estudiantes los cuales son conocidos como "Estudiantes Definitivos" en los cuales cada uno destaca en diferentes cosas. Al llegar a la escuela el protagonista siente un mareo y se desmaya para despues despertar dentro de la escuela junto a los demas estudiantes, luego de presentarse cada uno de ellos llegan a la cancha donde se presenta uno de los antagonistas del juego "Monokuma". de ahi sera nuestra mision lograr salir de la academia resolviendo los asesinatos y descubrir quien es el culpable si no la queremos palmar.

En el post game es divertido cuando menos aunque algo tedioso de hacer para conseguir todos los regalos que nos aportan todos los alumnos. aunque al inicio es algo complicado, lo bueno que tiene es que las mejores de hab se mantienen haciéndonos mas fácil después de la primera partida.

Despues de mucho sudor y contratiempos consegui el 100% del juego lo cual recomiendo ya que es divertido tener las interacciones con cada uno de los estudiantes y descubrir sus secretos para llevarse mas con ellos.

128986512.review:
So real quick I actually have an extra 30 or so hours on this game but I mostly played it while my internet was out okay actual review:
This game has some of the worst written characters I've ever seen. The actual gameplay elements are pretty alright, but the characters oftentimes make that insufferable as well. You're given the option to spend time with the characters and get to know them better, which I did about half the time. The times I did, I was extremely disappointed as the characters proved to be completely one dimensional. They play to stereotypes and don't veer from that at all. There's the militant one, the mysterious one, the musclehead, the horny one, and it goes on. On one occasion I even talked to one of my favorite characters about their talent, which they basically told me was anime magic and not actual skill, which completely ruined one of the few characters I found tolerable. The big bad of the whole game had such an annoying voice and expressions that I took my headphones off for the last 3 hours and sat in silence as that was so much preferable to hearing them speak.
The story of the game is very back end heavy. You're given basically nothing to work on and pretty much can't speculate about anything that's happening until an absolutely massive lore dump at the end, which consists of a combination of things that are so stereotypical and at the same time, so stupidly outlandish that I can't believe more than one person green lit this.
I don't know man, I don't get it. It's a fairly decent murder mystery, but wow everything else is so unforgivable. There's a lot of other games out there that are way more worth your time and money than this D tier mess.

128943544.review:
[b]This is my personal opinion and should not discourage anyone from buying this game if they so desire.[/b]

Ok, I think I have been holding off on this review for a long time. 

A few questions before we proceed:

- Do you like anime?
if yes,
- Do you like visual noves?
if yes OR no,
- Do you like your expectations to be twisted and you suddently start loving a genre you had no idea was this good?
If yes,

What can I say? The Danganronpa series left a scar in my brain that cannot be returned. The sadest reality of the Danganronpa games is that there really aint no reason to replay them. They have zero replay value, but the game that you get is nothing short but a MASTERPIECE.
And I don't use that term lightly. It truly is a masterpiece. All 3 games in my opinion.

If you choose to proceed with buying the game and trying it from here, I apologise in advance. You WILL beg for more Danganronpa even after you've finished all 3 relevant games. The games, in my humble opinion, are THAT good. I found myself absorbed in Danganronpa and, given the nature of the series, got terrified of just googling the games. You DO NOT want to get spoiled. Absolutely under any circumstances. Once you start playing the series, you have thus born a new form of internet paranoia, the terror of getting Danganronpa spoilers.

The price is SUPER fair in my book. The game is so well crafted and the sequels are equal, if not even better, in quality and story. I absolutely adored the games and all the characters. Mostly all. 
The jokes are great, even the naughty ones and the fanservice ones. I found myself bursting out laughing several times! The soundtrack is absolute Banger too! I absolutely urge you to play Danganronpa. I want you to suffer as bad as I am. I would slit the throat of a goat under the dark moon Morrslieb if I could bring the tiniest hint about a new Danganronpa game. A reboot of the series or whatever. Anything! The games are THAT good and it's almost like a formula you cannot fail on (get good detective mysteries and absolute wack characters and you're set basically).

Did I forget to mention to BUY Danganronpa and play the series? 
That comes from someone who generally don't like Visual novels. This is in a league of it's own. As far as I am concerned, this game puts other Visual novels to a laughable shame. 

Peace!

The only game that I've played like this is Ace Attorney.

I hate this game and I don't get why people like it so much. 
The story is nonsensical even by anime standards, the "mystery mastermind" is obvious from the get go and their motivation doesn't make a lick of sense, the characters are bland and the over-the-top murder cut-scenes are tasteless. 
This is coming from someone who's a huge Ace Attorney fan, so I enjoy visual novels, anime and sillyness, but Danganronpa is just not good.
If you're a major edge lord who doesn't really care about principles of good storytelling and/or logic this game might be for you, otherwise just play Ace Attorney instead...

128500276.review:
An overall amazing visual novel experience. The story is engaging, full of a colorful cast of characters, nail biting moments, interesting twists & turns, great writing, and asatisfying conclusion. The post-game content is quite plentiful as well. Court Sessions have full voice acting and the voicr performances for pretty much a of the characters are fantastic. 

Gameplay mostly relies on your drive to progress the story and learn more about the setting and characters. It is very hard to not get attached to it all. Kyoko is my favorite character and she definitely isn't on my long list of waifus. The game mechanics really shine in the trials where you have to figuratively shoot down people's argument with bullets that hint at the truth. Soundtrack is fantastic and fits the tone and setting spectacularly. Character Art and Visual Presentation is great for it being a PS Vita visual novel ported to PC. 

If you love anime aesthetic visual novels, you will love this game. Just be aware of the dark themes that this game has.

9 / 10

128248463.review:
Super fun game. It’s the first proper game (out of 40) that I finished on steam. Thoughts from a lazy casual easily-bored gamer and mystery lover:

What I liked:
- murder mystery for beginners and experienced 
- loveable & distinctive characters 
- ease of use and QoL (hate walking and wasting your time? Here’s a teleport feature. Dislike randomly clicking everywhere until you finally get a clue? Here’s a button to show which items are a clickable)
- variety of deaths
- interesting ‘punishments’
- overarching plot
- some character development
- the gimmicky features grow on you (hated it initially but it’s probably what made solving the murder all the more fun) 

What I disliked:
- a little too easy (but still hella fun)
- lots of clues are spoonfed to you by npc’s instead of you using them on the trial
- some questions during trial are too vague
- glaring plotholes. suspension of disbelief is a must
- panic talk. The hell is this? Has got nothing to do with solving mysteries.
- monokuma theatre. Colossal waste of time
- chapter 2 hangman. You’ll prolly have to google the answer to this one since it doesn’t make sense and is prolly a localisation error.

Overall, a really good game. Recommended.

127119442.review: My favorite part of playing visual novels is holding down the CTRL button to skip walls of text, I'm only American so you all should understand that Americans can't read any letter that isn't U, S or A, and while this game has plenty of GAMEPLAY besides the brain aneurysm that is trying to figure out what artstyle this game is going for, legendary fast food worker turned sound-cloud rapper Masafumi Takada can surely keep you awake during this game and make you rave like you accidentally walked into a VIP gentleman's club in Miami. I honestly have no idea because I never read through visual novels but I can tell you that the best girl is actually a boy, and the best bro is actually a girl, so forgive me if I am just as confused as a pro-life republican trying to choose between saving a small child or a case of 25 perfectly frozen fertilized embryos from a burning house. From what I can gather the main character was a online r/TheDonald lurker who got invited to a meet up with other redditors and they basically got tricked into thinking the earth was flat so they started having multiple arguments with each other like "if the earth was flat then how come anime girl there has such thicc curves?' and then they throw pepto at each other until one of them finally realizes how cringe they are to the human eye and yells at a woman, causing the biggest most awful, most tragic reddit moderator to shut down the thread for hate speech and not respecting women, but yeah solid game, gets a IGNorance score of 9/11, music is great but being outside and respecting women is greater.

124770779.review:
Tried it very late - as many bought on sale as I heard a lot of good things about it and it waited patiently for it's time in my backlog.

In general, if you played Ace Attorney series or simply like investigations, here you will have six chapters to solve murder mysteries. Compared to Ace Attoreny those are fairly easy, with lot of clues easily given and murder cases itself being very logical when you get gist of each one. What is different is presentation - all characters and situations are completely over the top and very dynamic. The trials and investigations have a lot of smaller mechanics added, which makes it more fast-paced. Except rhythmic mini-game during trial, which is sometimes bullshit - all are just something to keep that crazy theme of the game rolling.

Story itself is pretty solid, it's easily 20 hours of read and play through with no slog to it really. At the beginning it might be bit confusing as there's not enough descirptions for some of the actions you can do, but you easily get hang of it. I've also really liked big cast of characters from the beginning - while at very beginning it is bit overwhelming, it quickly sorts itself out and adds a lot of unique flavor to this game.

If you want to play on Steam Deck, it works really well. Only at launch you need to touch control press "Launch" as this is port and have its own launcher for setup, but out-of-box it works well. I had just one moment where I had game freeze for 20 seconds in Chapter 3 that might have been some temporary out of memory on my device, but except that it run really well. It's one of those perfect titles for Steam Deck to play on go or in bed.

124490136.review:
Danganronpa gets a lot of flack in internet discourse nowadays from all angles, a lot of people shit on the game itself, and a lot of people shit on the fandom, and hate the game as a result. Is this criticism well founded? Or is it just a classic example of people being negative for fun?

The original Danganronpa release in Japan over a decade ago, to pretty high praise. It was renound for its unique artstyle, mixing expressive pop art with dark and macabre tones, as well as its colorful cast of characters, and the tension and mystery that came from (at the time) a pretty unique scenario; the killing game. These elements are what drew me in a few years ago, and they totally engrossed me. I absolutely loved this game. I got all of my friends into it, and played it over and over to get all of the achievements. It wasn't until fairly recently that the game changed from being a pretty niche, well respected game to a popular franchise synonymous with cringe, which begs the question. Were we all just blind teenagers eating up something that totally lacks substance, or does this game just get a bad rap?

Well, I would say that it has definitely begun to show its age, it still absolutely holds up. The artstyle definitely looks amateur in some areas, but it's still just as charming as ever. The plot and writing tend to be pretty goofy and melodramatic at times, it's still pretty charming, and the reveals still have some pretty good weight. The characters are still a ton of fun, and it's easy to see why so many people, (myself included) fell in love with them years ago. It's got its slow spots for sure, it can take a really long time to get going, and a couple chapters just totally flop, so it's definitely not for the kinda player who lives for adrenaline, but the trials and character moments tie it all together for me.

So overall, would I still reccomend this game to people today? Yeah, but mostly as an introduction to the rest of the series. Danganronpa Triggerhappy Havoc lays an excellent baseline for the rest of the series, and while it still absolutely hold up on its own, it's only a sliver of a pretty awesome series. Check it out if you love mystery games and don't mind some reading and point and click exploration. 7/10.

123640435.review:
Danganronpa has a very special place in my heart. This is my favorite video game series ever made. After playing through all 4 games, 100% completion for two of them, I can say that this is still the best game in the series. All of the characters in this game are so interesting and enjoyable. They all have their own complexities and quirks, and they are a joy to learn more about. This game has the strongest cast of the main trilogy.
The story is so well done. Despite being an odd concept, they really hit it out of the park. The game is somehow funny, while also really hitting the emotional beats it strives for. It has great suspense and dread built in, and you really do become invested. I love the message of Hope and Despair, and it really helped me in a time where I was going through a lot of difficulties. Also the strongest story overall.
The game play is standard visual novel flair. You click on items to look at them, and at the characters to talk to them. The trials are a bit more complex, but really this is quite simple. The other two games do definitely have more interesting game play, but for a visual novel, it suffices. 
School Mode is also a fun reward for completing the first game. It allows you to talk to the characters you may not have had time for when you were playing the campaign. It also allows you to go on special hang-outs with the characters to get hearts. You even get a special ending for each character you get 10 hearts with. It's fun, and a relaxing mode to learn more about the characters.
Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone. It's engaging, humorous, and powerful. Even if your on the fence, give it a shot. I know you won't regret it. (Just ignore the fandom.) 

Grade: A+

123161761.review: I have played this game (and the whole trilogy) a few times already on PS4; I couldn't miss out on the trilogy bundle here and I'm set on getting all the achievements. Aside from that, the Danganronpa series is iconic. The plot is quite interesting but the characters and artstyle really made it the huge hit that it is right now. Some of them are memorable and complex. Danganronpa is a visual novel with minigame mechanics (shooting evidence, hangman gambit, rhythm games and a few other things); I'm not an expert in game genres but I think it's a really valid visual novel. I don't mind reading a lot (if you do, this game is probably not for you...) but despite the huuuuge amount of dialogue I didn't find it monotone. Trigger Happy Havoc is the most plain of the trilogy; while it does set the atmosphere and plot, the second and third game have a much thicker plot and interesting twist. The characters are quite interesting but the dynamics and relationships between them (as well as the gameplay) get better from game to game. I really recommend giving this series a chance!

122788612.review:
[h1] Dang!-ganronpa is a really good game![/h1]

After way to long I finally got around to playing Trigger Happy Havoc: Danganronpa and as said in the title - it's a really good game!

It's a murder mystery visual novel with dating elements, despite that description making it sound very generic it is anything but. 

Briefly speaking the game is very unique, it has engaging gameplay along with a dynamic cast of loveable character, plus some pretty neat art-styles. Most importantly the story is generally well written and despite the game being 10 years old has aged shockingly well. 

If you like mystery games, anime or visual novels I highly recommend checking out Danganronpa immediately - do it now! Its the type of game that the less you know going in the better and I'm going to go into more detail now, so this is your final warning.

Firstly the gameplay. Like most visual novels the majority of gameplay involves reading and clicking the A button, but Danganronpa does also quite surprisingly involve First Person Movement sections. In which you walk around the setting of the game, Hope's Peak Academy. It's also includes more interactive trial sections that involve a variety of different minigames that span from the player pointing out contradictions, to playing hangman with a gun, to a rhythm game. These section are really unique and add a lot of spice to the otherwise bland visual novel gameplay. Even when stumped by certain arguments or when struggling rhythmically I was having fun.

The art-style of the game is very anime-esque, but has an edgy and almost Western streak to it that keep it different from the rest. All the sprites are charming and give characters a whole lot of life. The game also features CGs which uses same proportions and general structure, but have an extreme amount of dept in shading. Making them stand out from the sprites and giving them a powerful level of materiality. Finally I can't not talk about the closing argument's which take the form of reconstruction the entire game as a comic. This is another fun gameplay mechanic which just has the best art-style, its totally subjective but I just adore it.

Before moving onto the written and conclusion, I want to draw attention to the voice acting in this game. All the character's are voiced, ranging from small audio snippets to accompany text to entirely voice sections during more important segments. I played the English version myself, but the English voice actors did an absolutely phenomenal job. Each and every performance brought the characters to life even further and were packed with emotion. Whether it be the most random gibberish you've heard or an emotional breakdown you can tell the voice actors put in the all consistently.

Finally the writing. In general the writing of the characters and the story itself was good, with a few exceptions here and there. Unfortunately the game does not go without flaw or plot hole, but these flaws aren't ruining don’t take from the overall experience. 

There are many lovable characters who are good friends and nice people. But more impressively there are characters who are uptight assholes, yet they're written such that you enjoy disliking them. Wonderful antagonistic character that you take great pleasure in seeing them rightfully struck down from their high horse cough Togami cough. Personally my favourite character is the serial killer, Genocide Jack - she's so crazy and silly!

The story is interesting and fully of mysteries and twists all they way, constantly building suspense towards the final climax. Many points caught me completely off guard and surprised me. However even the less intense moments of the game, akin to filler content, are populated with the most bizarre writing and meta-jokes that made me laugh.

So yeah, all in all Dangenronpa is a really good game, if you haven't played it - you should! As for me - I look forward to playing its sequel, Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair.

I have watched the original anime quite long ago, only recently have I decided to try this game out and I have to say that while there are shortcomings, such as lack of character depth in my opinion, the game was a good experience.

Some technical things to note:
-This seems like a common trend in Danganronpa ports to PC, but the audio also do not seem to be the best of quality.  Again, everything is distinguishable and its not bad or immersion breaking, just not as clean.

-On DirectX render, I tended to get a white line on the edge of my screen, turning it to OpenGL fixed the problem.

121592716.review:
I have 100% completed this game four times across four different platforms. I think I can safely say that this game is great.

It's far from flawless, certainly not for everyone and its fandom can get... interesting at times, but if you are looking for a solid visual novel and classic if somewhat trope-ish anime death game experience, I would highly recommend this!

The characters are memorable (although I do have a soft spot for Danganronpa 2's cast), the story is equal parts gripping, funny, genuinely disturbing and outright ludicrous and the mechanics are solid and keep you engaged with each trial as you search for the culprit. The music is amazing, the investigation music being a personal favourite of mine.

The game can drag as the trials become more complex leading to bizarre twists and outcomes that will have you rolling your eyes, but I dare you to not want to know who killed who as the investigations suck you in. Some characters, though memorable, can feel a bit one-note at times, you will definitely have some who are your favourites and some you would rather not spend too much time with.

All in all, Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is an excellent experience that falls just shy of being amazing but nevertheless will confuse, shock, intrigue and amuse you as it pulls you into a crazy world of murder, psychotic stuffed bears, plot twists and despair. A solid introduction to a series that has players searching every area of the crime scene and wondering whose turn it will be for "punishment time".

121563852.review:
Awesome game. It is a lot of reading so folks who aren't used to that, it might not be for you.
This game has a pretty unique style with the overly simple environments with 2D objects. It would seem that the budget that wasn't used for graphics was thrown into the writing department since this game has very interesting mysteries and writing that keeps your interest always piqued. 
     Character designs are fun and memorable and those of you that think of this as just another anime game made to satisfy the bottomless pits that the fans' stomachs are, imho you're wrong. These characters are well fleshed out (some more than others) and the story and mystery is the main focus, which they did really well. Also the class trials are very engaging and satisfying when you piece together everything clue by clue. Tiny warning though, sometimes for someone like me with a bad short term memory things get very confusing while figuring out what clue fits a statement if it's not explicitly said in the clue's description so while most of the trial is fine, I do have some problems at times, but nowhere near enough to make me avoid or recommend avoiding the game.
     One thing I would recommend if you're completely new to the series: don't google anything about it. It's spoilers galore and the fandom can drive you away as there are especially many diehard fans for this game. Not saying they're bad, but they can get a bit, how would you say it... passionate. Also the fans get a bad rap for being cringy. 
Don't care about the DR fan stereotypes, just play it for yourself and experience the story!

121488756.review:
"danganronpa: trigger happy havoc" is, first and foremost, an among us-like game and is absolutely not afraid to wear its inspirations on its sleeve. how well it lives up to the experience and memory of the original is debatable, however. in my humble experience, having involuntarily played through the game's first class trial a few times already, i can confidently say that "danganronpa_1" is certainly a game.

starting off, the first thing players might notice is that the setting has been drastically changed from the vast expanse of outer space to an average-looking, non-assuming high school, curiously named after the pope. as such, the crewmembers have been appropriately adapted and the main cast is now instead mainly comprised of high schoolers. moreover, rather than distinguishing characters by their spacesuit colours, as was so core to the identity of the original among us, the developers have strolled down avant-garde avenue and decided instead to give each member of the cast a personality and unique design, as well as their own 'ultimate' talent, be it programming, baseball, or even ???. it's just a shame there's no ultimate imposter, but the possibility of dlc is there, if not just to appease the old generations who still cling on to pillars of the old world, but i digress. this alteration, as unexpected as it may be, is welcome and while the simplicity of the original is to be dearly missed, i'm certain that this new step is for the better. 

despite the veering off of the setting, the main plotline, thankfully, gives much needed solace and anchors "danganronpa the first" to its roots; the plotline will be familiar to anyone who's played among us in the past two decades: stuck in a confined area with other people, you (as the player) must survive a deadly game and weed out the imposters. one notable consideration is that in this game, anyone can be an imposter. this newfound freedom of choice seems to mirror, quite accurately, the direction that our outside world is heading in, intentional or not, and may leave a select few players disgruntled. for the rest of the population, however? we will remain completely gruntled. in fact, i bet most will not even notice these parallels. 

and now we get to the gameplay. "dragonromper, trigger happy" is, at its core, a word-like game, but i can't read. 
as much as i cannot stand this lack of consideration towards unable-bodied players, especially in this current century, i will still give this game the benefit of the doubt and trust that the reading bits are interesting and grammatically correct. despite this oversight, the game manages to work in some other enthralling gameplay mechanics such as walking and even sprinting, archaic systems of movement as they may be.

apart from the difficult movement-based sections, there are the class trials, which is where the meat of the game lies. during these sequences, your job is to determine who is, for lack of better words, sussy. surprisingly, there is no text nor voice chat, and you must instead rely on specific prompts and clues collected from investigations prior to, for lack of better words, sus a classmate out. this area of the game is certainly a step backwards from the original and heavily constrains player agency. nevertheless, as disappointing as it is, i can understand the removal of such a vital feature in order to accommodate shy and socially inept players, who, for reasons unknown, seem to occupy a large portion of the gaming community nowadays.

121276463.review:
A thrilling and funny murder-mystery scenario wherein characters you want to live will drop like flies while that person you thought would definitely bite the dust keeps on going. It is similar to Ace Attorney, but the trials are more stressful due to time pressure and minigames, and there is a set number of characters which you get to know in a sort of dating-sim mode between cases. Like AA, though, the music is awesome and instantly memorable.

I really enjoyed trying to figure out each case, and I couldn't connect all the dots of any of the cases before near the end of the trial due to the good twists (even if the culprit was sometimes obvious). I especially remember fondly how you have to retell the story of the whole case at the end of each trial, accompanied by great music and comic visuals. Very few if any of the logical leaps were asking too much, but there were a few frustrating times where I couldn't figure out how to say something and just spammed every option on all answers or looked it up. The overall story was pretty engaging too.

121054848.review:
[h1] Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc [/h1]

Known for having quite a well-known fandom, the Danganronpa games are known for being wacky and very popular. Unlike many other detective games, Danganronpa tests the logic of the player through various mini games. As the first game in the series, it is important to see how it stands as a game on it's own. 

[h1] Characters [/h1]

Danganronpa is known for it's characters being very "anime" like. Many of the characters in Trigger Happy Havoc are extremely wacky compared to others. This is a downside in some ways as observant players will be able to predict which characters are most likely to make it to the end (which are usually the more tame characters). Despite this, it is extremely interesting to see how some of these characters connect to each other and seeing some of them develop. I wouldn't say there is a single character that I would consider useless as they all have their own individual strengths and weaknesses.

[h1] Story [/h1]

Danganronpa is a game that is best experienced blind as there are many plot twists that would be ruined otherwise. It is also engaging to the player that they go into this fully blind as it makes it hard to predict who is alive, who is dead and who is "The Blackened"? Unfortunately, Danganronpa's fandom, has made it extremely hard to avoid spoilers. There are small examples but one big example of this stems from this game. I will not describe in detail this twist but it is part of the reason why going in blind to this game is good. 15 students are placed in a "Killing Game". It is up to the player to solve the overall nature of the "Killing Game" while also focusing on each murder case each chapter.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Danganronpa's gameplay is unique in the sense that there are several parts to it. 

As a visual novel, you will be reading A LOT of text. And most of it is not voice acted. Text is voiced usually in really important scenes or during the Class Trials. You also have free time events. Where you can become closer with your classmates and unlock skills for use in the Class Trials. Investigation are also a thing. It is important players fully engage during these investigations as it helps greatly. And then we come to the main part: Class Trials. 

Depending on the difficulty players choose for Logic and Action, it will greatly affect how hard these are and how much the player is left to connect the dots themselves. Personally, I recommend that players play on Mean difficulty for both Logic and Action as it greatly helps the experience and makes you feel like you are actively taking part in the Trial. 

You will play mini games in these class trials. Some are straight forward: hit the contradiction. However some are a lot more wacky. The main example of this is a mini game where you must essentially play a rhythm game. If the idea of wacky mini games puts you off, I would suggest you stay away from this franchise as these are a core part of the games.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Overall, I would say that Trigger Happy Havoc is a very good game and starting point for the Danganronpa franchise. If the idea of lots of unvoiced text and wacky mini games puts you off, you won't enjoy playing this game. However, if you are fans of the detective/mystery genre, i would highly suggest you pick this up. UK price is £14.99, which is worth it. These games are often on sale as well so it is well worth the price. Don't let the fandom of this game put you off. Most, if not all, forms of media have terrible fandoms.

Rating: 9/10 (Really good game. Only thing that is annoying is the fact that completion is a pain due to a side mode included in most of these games)

This overall writing is just a total, 100% undeniable poop fest of the devil!

All in all, I feel screwed over and like the game tricked me into wasting time.

all this talk about [spoiler]"hope" and "despair"[/spoiler] as if those were some sort of tangible entities felt really silly and forced and honestly cheesy as hell. It made NO sense. also pseuso deep. I mean, I really really hoped and expected that there was more to it, but nah. Just blahblah, so cheesy it makes you wanna go vegan.

Anyone who thinks it's actually "good" is either very young, has no intellectual standards at all and/or has objectively bad taste and probably also thought the last GOT season was well written. Sorry not sorry.

I am so disappointed. I finished the game a few months ago and started this review with a relative good mood and got more bitter and mad the longer I thought about it. Although the pros in terms of quantity clearly outweigh the cons, all in all, the bad ending ruined EVERYTHING and while writing I started to remember the feeling of being fooled by this spawn of satan of an ending more and more and now I'm totally furious and cannot recommend this trainwreck of a sh1tsh0w at ALL!

It is, in a nutshell, a really bad and childish explanation that seems like a very lazy cop-out.
As pretentious and insolent this undeniably probably sounds, it felt more or less like an attack on my intelligence! 
Honestly, I don't think it could have sucked more, even if the MC suddenly woke up and it was all "just a dream" (aka the "plot twist" we all came up with in our first writing assignment in elementary school)

I was soooo hyped throughout the whole game for the grand reveal and thorougly enjoyed it, because I thought, no, I was CONVICED this has to be such a cool explanation why the hell a certain little event should lead to basically [spoiler] the apocalypse[/spoiler], because otherwise this would be ridiculous, right?! WRONG! I mean, it IS ridiculous, but the great "explanation" was, it is, because it is and we, the authors, said so!!!

People comparing this to Zero Escape are insane. In Zero Escape, which I LOVE, things actually also matter in the big picture. The plot is a very carefully crafted construct of a lot of different storylines that beautifully come together to birth an amazing symphony of a story. Things that are bad are ACTUALLY bad and actually make sense WHY they are bad and why they matter in such a grand scale of things and HOW they happened at all. (also explained very well, in great detail and always accentuated with real life science and facts.

Zero escape, story-wise, is something I would recommend to someone who doesn't think they'll like anime (which VN pretty much are, even with 3D) because they believe them to be childish and silly, because it will prove them otherwise.

Danganronpa THH is something I would definitely NOT recommend, as it will provide them with the false assumption that they were correct about all the bad stereotypes there are about anime.

[spoiler]Sorry, but a bunch of teenies being slaughtered at school definitely is NOT an event that will lead to the whole world collectively falling into "despair" (such a cheesy stupid statement once you realize there is nothing more behind it!!) and will be so devastating the world will be forever ruined. Something like that sure is a tragedy, but aside from the victim's next of kin, no one's life will be shattered forever and no one will probably even remember it happened in a few month's time, let alone people worldwide![/spoiler]

120200069.review: This game is painful but rewarding, in a Doki Doki Literature Club sort of way. It uses the fact that its anime to its advantage, so when things are going well they seem innocuous enough, and when they aren't you'll feel it. If you like the Ace Attorney games, Danganronpa has some crossover with that series in terms of gameplay and general flow, and even a sort of suspension-of-disbelief factor (it takes place in a "real world", but some real interesting stuff happens akin to channeling spirits in Ace Attorney, etc.). Anime or not, Danganronpa has a good way of building characters up and then knocking them down, whether you like it or not, and showing you what characters are truly made of and why they act the way that they do, even if they initially seem two-dimensional. The narrative however is interesting, and you'll probably grow attached to at least some of the characters, so it's worth it to play through to the end. The voice acting is also a nice touch. In terms of the series as a whole, Danganronpa 1 is a good game with some flaws and interesting nuances (for better or worse) that you should play if it interests you. Danganronpa 2, its sequel, is probably objectively better, but can only really be fully appreciated once you play Danganronpa 1, for both gameplay/writing and continuity/story. Silly, yes, but dark, too. And yet, it's worth it.

120148522.review:
Steam is weird. This game is rated "Overwhelmingly Positive", but it is an objectively bad game. Don't get me wrong, the story is interesting. The gameplay on the other hand is bad. At times, terrible. Chalk it up to our friends the "Japanese Culture Connoisseurs" so prevalent on steam being less than objective.

This game was originally made for PSP in 2010 and the gameplay would have bad even on that system back then. Apparently, this was meant to be a visual novel, but the developers were concerned that VNs had declined in popularity in Japan at the time, so they opted to shoehorn in some actual gameplay. 

Given that the story is pretty engaging, initially it's worth slogging through the clunky interface and poorly explained, not entertaining mechanics. However, the point I just got to in the game bombarded me with the worst of these mechanics in a section where you can't save your progress for almost 2 hours straight. It was exhausting. I'm likely not going to continue playing this game. I'll probably watch the Anime and be done with it.

Still here? Okay, I'll elaborate briefly on the mechanics. It's mostly an extremely clunky point and click. Navigation is very tedious. It asks you if you're sure you want to move to a different room every time, then you have to wait for it to load, then you have to watch it be constructed which is supposed to be cool I guess. The trials are supposed to be the meat of the game, where you go through and piece together what happened. It starts off promisingly, seemingly reminiscent of Ace Attorney, but then goes off the rails. There's only ever a few options to interject and they become increasingly illogical. Then you have to kind of shoot the thing you want to argue against, but it's super annoying and not fun. Then you do some stupid rhythm game that isn't explained and doesn't work well and isn't fun. Then you do a sort of jigsaw puzzle. It's just awful.

119860525.review:
I'm keeping this review short. I'm tired as I write this.

The game is really good. all the mysteries are, well, mysterious. all the twists are very unexpected, including who dies (with some exceptions). all the characters are well thought out, as are their free time events. the game is really funny and dramatic, with any breathing time loaded with character development! the class trial system is incredibly unique, and the murders are very interesting, if far-fetched sometimes.

however, this game isn't without its flaws. the biggest one being, you can only really play it once. It's a murder mystery game; that's the whole thing about it. once you know the mysteries, and how to solve them, all that's left is dialogue and perfection. you can get the dialogue through the School Mode, and perfection will be really easy since you know the answers. speaking of easy...

the game was way too easy. I set myself to the hardest difficulty, and got A on every trial. and not because I'm smart -- I suck at stuff like this normally, -- the mysteries were just too... simple. the answer is either obvious, or takes little to no time to find. however, randomly, you're thrown a question that takes a really long time to decipher an answer from, or you really need to use trial and error -- a thing you're not supposed to do -- to find the answer. one of the hangman's gambit sections was entirely BS; I got lucky to find the answer. 

I do not like school mode. they tried to let you hang out with any of the characters at your leisure, with a resource-gathering game to keep you entertained, but they failed. As I said before, you can see their free time event scenes, but you can also take them "on a trip" i.e. a date, to one of six places in the school. at first, it's charming, but it quickly gets annoying, as these dates are incredibly short, consisting of one choice, a reaction from the person, and a cut to when it's done. there's a reward in the form of a "secrets reveal" from a character you do this to enough, at day 50. I don't care enough to do it. Originally, I intended to do this with Chihiro, but after maxing them out, I'd need to play the dumb mini-game another 35-some times, and I don't want to, because it's really boring!
outside of that, interacting with the characters in school mode feels way more useless when we're not in peril. "tragedy creates bonds" and all that. when there's no tragedy, and I've already been through tragedy with them, it just deflated all emotion I had about the characters. If you wanted replay value for a murder mystery game, change up who dies, who kills, etc. 

Despite all my gripes with this game, the first playthrough was amazing, i gotta say. that's why I recommend this. Not for replay value, but for the once-in-a-lifetime experience that is this game, and its successors. that's why I rate this game a "great"

8/10, but I cannot play it again

PS i dont think I can play the second one properly since I watched the Game Grumps play it...
PPS yes, this is the shortened version of my review

118952811.review:
A fantastic game, which can show that you don't need to have a ton of resources in order to make a good product. It is a game which sticks to the basics and excels in all departments of story, music and gameplay without having barren virtual worlds, ultra-realistic graphics or a story which only serves to move the main character from one explosion to another.

The story is intensely exciting and excels in keeping you at the edge of your seat at all times, even though you're just reading lines of text and watching the scene unfold before you The characters are so much fun to play with and their character arcs have such an incredible depth that makes the most realistic-looking characters from other games feel like cardboard cutouts. The setting of Hope's Peak Academy is a fantastic one and shows the creativity of the developers to weave a story around a place wherein every room, corridor or even a bathroom can hide a mystery, waiting for you to discover and unfold. 

The gameplay is quite simple and does not try to get too intricate, where its brilliance lies in. A great example is how the game plays with the concept of rules, where you'll say "oh, there are only 5-6 rules in the  Hope's Peak Academy Handbook, what could go wrong?" and this game goes on to show how intricately those can be broken, which makes the detective aspects of the game all the more exciting as you search for clues that will leave you at the end thinking that "dang, I didn't know they could do this!" With regards to the soundtrack, every single track is an absolute enjoyment to hear. They never get boring despite being repeatedly used and some of the music used in the class trials is arguably the best. 

All this being said, its a phenomenal experience that is a must-play.
