118841007.review:
(I played 1 and 2 on switch, and here's a [url=https://imgur.com/rDb7E6n]screenshot[/url] to prove that.)

Danganronpa is a series of detective mystery visual novels. The first game, Trigger Happy Havoc, came out in 2010 on the PSP. What Spike Chunsoft didn't realize was that years later, Danganronpa would absolutely explode as a series. 

Playing this game, its pretty easy to see why. It takes the killing game concept, and turns it on its head. Instead of an all out battle of strength, its more of a game of the mind. Where you must kill, but you can't be caught, and those who aren't dead or a killer must figure out who the killer is to save themselves. The game also radiates a style and energy unlike any visual novel of the time. Something as utterly unique as Danganronpa was bound to blow up at some point. Especially during the time. But unfortunately, the series fails to execute on the potential of the concept.

But that's for future games. Let's talk about Danganronpa 1, which was overall pretty fun. I don't see why the game is sitting at a 96%, I would personally give it around an 85%. But then again, the game is so unique and is also filled with eccentric and likable characters, so I can see why that would excuse many of the games shortcomings. 

Lets start with unfettered positives. The game has a fantastic visual style from the get-go. The music is also great, and the voice acting is also fantastic. I also generally enjoyed the exploration aspect, going around Hope's Peak and such. 

Now for the story. After playing the other games, this one seems almost quaint by comparison, but I enjoyed it overall. Its well paced and has nice twists. Not much to complain about, but not much to praise either. 
The gameplay is also decent. The system of truth bullets broken up by questions and minigames is a great system. 

In terms of negatives, I really was disappointed by how simple this games logic is. Even on the hardest difficulty, its not hard to deduce what the game wants you to shoot when. 

But overall, this is a great start to the series, lets hope the games evolve from here.
In the context of the greater series, I would only recommend this game to see what all the fuss is about, and just hold off on the rest. Don't trudge through the rest of the series like I did.

118330479.review:
Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is by no means the best visual novel out there, but the story of a collection of teenage prodigies all confined in a large school, where the only way out is to get away with murder, this makes for a very interesting game indeed.

The dialogue is top notch for a visual novel.  The US voice acting is very good and I really enjoy the expressions of emotions from each character.  You really get a sense of what each student's personality is like over the passing of in game days, even if some of them come off a bit stereotypical  

What makes this game fun is a few factors.  Firstly, it's the paced story telling and the gravitation that a gamer will have towards the various characters.  Second is the investigation aspect.  When things go down and you have to get your facts in order, it's really fun to use your deductive skills in order to play out what is going on before you get to the last fun factor: the class trials.  This is where some people might compare it to games like Phoenix Wright but to me it's way different, as the spoken dialogue and collective reasoning between all the students to find the culprit is astounding.  They also have some nifty ways to mix up the questioning and accusations by having you do mini games.  

There's a very lite relationship system in place, there's exploration, there are mini-games after the end game and this game can/should be played through multiple times!  

This is one of my games that is in my top 25 games for sure!

117838585.review:
EDIT: After playing through 1, 2 and V3 I wanted to leave an endnote that while the trilogy is still pretty phenomenal, this game is still the best in terms of story. If you're curious about Danganronpa but on the fence like I was, pick this up during a sale, play it, and if you enjoy it buy the other two.

I was hesitant to start this game because the cardboard cutout art style for the characters really annoyed the crap out of me, but I picked it up for 8 bucks during a sale and liked it a LOT more than I expected to.
Unfortunately, Danganronpa has some very...sketchy? design choices that really prevent it from rising to greatness. The class trial segments of the game can be equal parts entirely too simple and infuriatingly confusing. It has the same problem that the Ace Attorney series occasionally has, where from the beginning you're told to look for contradictions in the testimony and refute them with evidence, but then the game will present you with statements that don't actually contradict your evidence, and you're supposed to match the evidence with the statement. It feels very backwards to me.

When I say "too simple," I mean that the game intentionally narrows down your options into only a few, or sometimes just 1 correct piece of evidence. Before each testimony the game shows you a selection of evidence that it's picked for you to use, and I think that this really hurts those "ah-ha!" moments you get by analyzing all your collected evidence for yourself. You collect a LOT of evidence in this game, and I was pretty disappointed to find out that a majority of it is barely presented in the trial segments. In some cases you'll even just ignore your evidence in favor of using statements to contradict other statements (which, to be fair, is a good idea and a mechanic I enjoyed.) The onslaught of evidence collected during investigation segments led me to believe the trials would be long, complicated, and with plenty of twists, but the game limiting your evidence and not forcing you to really get familiar with all of your clues, combined with the trials being over before you even realize it, dampen the satisfaction of solving each mystery.

The trial segments also feature multiple minigames that you must play in order to proceed. To be frank, these minigames do not in any way, shape or form enhance the feeling of pointing out a contradiction, and in some cases it just feels straight up childish. I kid you not, one of these minigames is literally playing hangman. I can't help but feel that if they had focused more on just the evidence v. testimony aspect of the trials, and gotten rid of the silly minigames, it would've been a lot more satisfying.

At the same time, those things I disliked about Danganronpa are what give it charm and personality, at the very least, it's different. What I can't excuse is the typical anime stuff thrown in, you've got a schoolgirl calling a character that abuses her "master," you've got cringeworthy talk about boobs in the middle of tense discussion,and you have an otaku "gamer" character that calls himself a pig and says they'll do anything to please their "mistress." All of that is to say, I hoped for less anime nonsense, but it doesn't detract much from the overall experience.

The story is pretty gripping, and did manage to hold my attention the entire way through, the twists near the end and the final trial really tie it up in a satisfying way. The element that 100% saves this game for me though, is the music. Holy shit. Nearly every track is an absolute banger, but the only problem is the pacing of it. In a matter of seconds you could change songs 3 or so times, and it can get incredibly jarring. But that feeling is quickly replaced by the absolute groove you feel when it plays, so I guess I'll excuse it.

This review's been mostly negative, but I do genuinely enjoy this game. You can probably tell that I have a huge Ace Attorney bias so if you like those games and you want something similar, this could scratch that itch.

117768803.review:
AITA for getting upset that my bridesmaid friend skipped my wedding

I've had a long engagement with my fiancé (got engaged December 2019),we were supposed to get married in 2021 but you can understand why that couldn't happen.

So our wedding happened this past weekend. One of my best friends was supposed to attend as a bridesmaid but she skipped last minute because of an emergency. To be honest I was mad she skipped because the emergency happened almost a week ago so she had time to figure things out and attend.

So what happened was that her fiancé got a car accident and was hospitalised. He was hospitalised for 5 days and on Friday he got discharged to go home. My friend had told me from the moment he got into the accident that she'll skip the wedding just to be sure and I told her we'll see. So when I saw that he got discharged on Friday I expected my friend to show up at the wedding after all since his situation is not as dangerous right now and I texted her but she said that she'll not be able to make it.

She kept saying how he's still not well and being discharged doesn't mean he can stay alone without care for many hours and since my wedding day would start at 9am on Saturday with the prepepartions etc, the ceremony would be at 7pm on Saturday evening and the reception/party would last until Sunday morning hours she couldn't be away from home for that long and she said she could compromise if she could only attend the ceremony.

I said I don't want her there just for the ceremony and she's a bridesmaid and supposed to be by my side the entire time. I also said that she should find him some care for the day so she can freely attend the wedding and I suggested inviting either her parents or a friend to stay with him for that day (his parents live far away). She said its not the same and she won't feel right being away for the entire day.

I got pretty upset because she seemed to totally disregard my wedding after so long making preparations and while I understand its her fiancé, I was mad she didn't find a compromise to attend. She claims her compromise would be to just attend the ceremony and then go home again but she's a bridesmaid. If she's not there for the full experience it would be pointless.

She said I'm an AH for making her feel guilty about caring for her hurt fiancé and she said that his situation takes priority over my wedding. She said she's not sorry for prioritising her SO's health over me at this point and if I was a good friend I'd understand instead of guilt tripping her and that I better not complain if I'm ever in a difficult situation and I need my husband's help and support and he chooses to attend someone's wedding over caring for his wife. AITA?

117744444.review: Danganronpa is kind of an interactive novel, i've played other games where most of the gameplay is listening to the characters talk and if you don't like these kinds of games then you probably wont like Danganronpa. The main point of the game is to solve murders that occur throughout the story. Bodies are discovered and you have a certain amount of time to find clues before the 'Class Trial" starts where the objective is to solve the murder. Honestly some of the murders are rather obvious but it still manages to keep you in the dark most of the time even if from the start you can see clearly who did what. now about the relationship system, you can spend free time to develop your relationship with your classmates and obtain skills that can be used in class trials but I felt like this system was lacking as you don't really have time to develop most relationships as the story moves rather quickly so you do not have time to develop the relationships of more than a few people and besides the perks there isn't really an in-depth story line to these relationships like in similar games such as persona. all in all Danganronpa is a very good game and I will be playing the sequels.

117666502.review:
This is a mystery murder game. If you are into detective games or want to check them out this one is done quite well and is [i]executed[/i] cleanly. The game gives you enough information to formulate an idea of what happened and has you use that information to reveal more and more. Leading into several 'Eureka!' moments throughout a single investigation / trial. 
The characters are distinct and memorable and it is fun seeing how they bounce off each other. The art and music do a splendid job of tying it all together. 

If you enjoy mystery or detective games, or are just interested this is an easy recommend.

This game has "unique" written all over it. 

The style, the gameplay, the story... Everything in it has its own personality. As if the mechanics alone are alive and I'm deeply enjoying every minute of it.

I can say, however, that the trials you encounter are a bit confusing as far as deciding evidence and such goes. The rhythm game alone is definitely interesting, to say the least. If you don't want to play a mystery game like this with so many odd mechanics, I would highly suggest the Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney trilogy that is also on Steam. Less confusing mechanics, in my opinion.

But so far, I can give this game a solid 8/10. I definitely recommend playing it.
